Unit 1: Introduction to Statistics

Lecture 1: What is Statistics?

Lecture 2: Probability Redux

Law of Large Numbers, Central Limit Theorem

Let X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​ be independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) random variables (r.v.). Let μ=E[X]\mu = \E[X]μ=E[X] the expectation and σ2=V[X]\sigma^2 = \V[X]σ2=V[X] the variance of these random variables.

We define the sample average of our XiX_iXi​ as:

Xˉn=1n∑i=1nXi\bar{X}_n = \frac1n \sum_{i=1}^nX_iXˉn​=n1​i=1∑n​Xi​

Law of Large Numbers (LLN):

(1.1)Xˉn\conv\P,a.s.μ\tag{1.1} \bar{X}_n \conv{\P, a.s.}\muXˉn​\conv\P,a.s.μ(1.1)

Where \P\P\P designs convergence in probability and a.s.a.s.a.s. convergence almost surely.

Central Limit Theorem (CLT):

(1.2)nXˉn−μσ\convdN(0,1)\tag{1.2} \sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n - \mu}{\sigma} \convd \mathcal{N}(0, 1)n​σXˉn​−μ​\convdN(0,1)(1.2)

Equivalently, we also have:

n(Xˉn−μ)\convdN(0,σ2)\sqrt{n}(\bar{X}_n - \mu) \convd \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)n​(Xˉn​−μ)\convdN(0,σ2)

If nnn is not large enough to apply the CLT, we have Hoeffding's inequality. If X∈[a,b]X \in [a, b]X∈[a,b] almost surely, then

P[∣Xˉn−μ∣≥ε]≤2exp⁡(−2nε2(b−a)2)\P[|\bar{X}_n - \mu| \geq \varepsilon] \leq 2\exp\left(-\frac{2n\varepsilon^2}{(b-a)^2}\right)P[∣Xˉn​−μ∣≥ε]≤2exp(−(b−a)22nε2​)

Properties of normal distributions

Linear transformation: given a random variable X∼N(μ,σ2)X \sim \Norm(\mu, \sigma^2)X∼N(μ,σ2),

(1.3)∀a,b∈R,aX+b∼N(aμ+b,a2σ2)\tag{1.3} \forall a, b \in \R, aX + b \sim \Norm(a\mu + b, a^2\sigma^2)∀a,b∈R,aX+b∼N(aμ+b,a2σ2)(1.3)

We can therefore standardize any normal distribution:

(1.4)Z=X−μσ∼N(0,1)\tag{1.4} Z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma} \sim \Norm(0, 1)Z=σX−μ​∼N(0,1)(1.4)

We therefore have:

P[u≤X≤v]=P[u−μσ≤Z≤v−μσ]\P[u \leq X \leq v] = \P\left[\frac{u-\mu}{\sigma} \leq Z \leq \frac{v-\mu}{\sigma}\right]P[u≤X≤v]=P[σu−μ​≤Z≤σv−μ​]

The standard normal probability is also symmetric, which means:

P[Z≥x]=P[Z≤−x]\P[Z \geq x] = \P[Z \leq -x]P[Z≥x]=P[Z≤−x]

The quantile of order 1−α1-\alpha1−α of a random variable XXX is the number qαq_\alphaqα​ such as:

(1.5)P[X≤qα]=1−α\tag{1.5} \P[X \leq q_\alpha] = 1 - \alphaP[X≤qα​]=1−α(1.5)

Types of convergence

Let (Tn)n(T_n)_n(Tn​)n​ be a sequence of random variables, and TTT a random variable (which can be deterministic).

Convergence almost surely:

(1.6)Tn\convasT  ⟺  \P[{ω:Tn(ω)\convT(ω)}]=1\tag{1.6} T_n \convas T \iff \P\left[\left\{\omega: T_n(\omega) \conv{} T(\omega)\right\} \right] = 1Tn​\convasT⟺\P[{ω:Tn​(ω)\convT(ω)}]=1(1.6)

Convergence in probability:

(1.7)Tn\convpT  ⟺  ∀ε>0,\P[∣Tn−T∣≥ε]\conv0\tag{1.7} T_n \convp T \iff \forall \varepsilon > 0, \P[|T_n - T| \geq \varepsilon] \conv{} 0Tn​\convpT⟺∀ε>0,\P[∣Tn​−T∣≥ε]\conv0(1.7)

Convergence in distribution:

(1.8)Tn\convdT  ⟺  \E[f(Tn)]\conv\E[f(T)]\tag{1.8} T_n \convd T \iff \E[f(T_n)] \conv{} \E[f(T)]Tn​\convdT⟺\E[f(Tn​)]\conv\E[f(T)](1.8)

for all function fff continuous and bounded.

Convergence almost surely implies convergence in probability, which implies convergence in distribution.

If the limit has a density, then convergence in distribution implies convergence in probability.

Operations on convergence

Let (Tn)n,(Un)n(T_n)_n, (U_n)_n(Tn​)n​,(Un​)n​ but two sequences of random variables, and T,UT, UT,U be two random variables. If

Tn→n→∞a.s./PT,Un→n→∞a.s/PUT_n \conv{a.s./\P} T, U_n \conv{a.s/\P} UTn​a.s./Pn→∞​T,Un​a.s/Pn→∞​U

then:

(1.9)Tn+Un→n→∞a.s/PT+U\tag{1.9} T_n + U_n \conv{a.s/\P} T + UTn​+Un​a.s/Pn→∞​T+U(1.9)
(1.10)TnUn→n→∞a.s/PTU\tag{1.10} T_nU_n \conv{a.s/\P} TUTn​Un​a.s/Pn→∞​TU(1.10)

if in addition, U≠0U \neq 0U̸​=0 almost surely, then

(1.11)TnUn→n→∞a.s/PTU\tag{1.11} \frac{T_n}{U_n} \conv{a.s/\P} \frac{T}UUn​Tn​​a.s/Pn→∞​UT​(1.11)

Slutsky's Theorem. Let u∈Ru \in \Ru∈R. If

Tn→n→∞(d)T,Un→n→∞PuT_n \convd T, U_n \convp uTn​(d)n→∞​T,Un​Pn→∞​u

then:

(1.12)Tn+Un→n→∞(d)T+u\tag{1.12} T_n + U_n \convd T + uTn​+Un​(d)n→∞​T+u(1.12)
(1.13)TnUn→n→∞(d)uTn\tag{1.13} T_nU_n \convd uT_nTn​Un​(d)n→∞​uTn​(1.13)

if in addition, u≠0u \neq 0u̸​=0, then

(1.14)TnUn→n→∞(d)1uT\tag{1.14} \frac{T_n}{U_n} \convd \frac1uTUn​Tn​​(d)n→∞​u1​T(1.14)

Continuous mapping theorem. Let f∈C(R)f \in \mathcal{C}(\R)f∈C(R). If

Tn→n→∞a.s./P/(d)TT_n \conv{a.s./\P/(d)}TTn​a.s./P/(d)n→∞​T

then:

(1.15)f(Tn)→n→∞a.s./P/(d)f(T)\tag{1.15} f(T_n) \conv{a.s./\P/(d)} f(T)f(Tn​)a.s./P/(d)n→∞​f(T)(1.15)

Unit 2: Foundation of Inference

Lecture 3: Parametric Statistical Models

Trinity of statistical inference: estimation, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.

Given X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dP\Xton \iid \PX1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dP, the goal is to learn the distribution P\PP.

A statistical model is defined as:

(2.1)\statmodel\tag{2.1} \statmodel\statmodel(2.1)

where

  • EEE is the sample space,
  • (\Pθ)θ∈Θ(\P_\theta)_{\theta \in \Theta}(\Pθ​)θ∈Θ​ is a family of probability measures on EEE,
  • Θ\ThetaΘ is called the parameter set.

The model is well specified if

(2.2)∃θ∈Θ,\Pθ=\P\tag{2.2} \exists \theta \in \Theta, \P_\theta = \P∃θ∈Θ,\Pθ​=\P(2.2)

The model is called:

  • parametric if Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd for some d∈Nd \in \Nd∈N,
  • non-parametric if Θ\ThetaΘ is infinite-dimensional,
  • semi-parametric if Θ=Θ1×Θ2\Theta = \Theta_1 \times \Theta_2Θ=Θ1​×Θ2​ where Θ1⊆Rd\Theta_1 \subseteq \R^dΘ1​⊆Rd is the parameter set we are interested in, and Θ2\Theta_2Θ2​ is the nuisance parameter set.

The parameter θ\thetaθ is called identifiable if the mapping θ↦Pθ\theta \mapsto \P_\thetaθ↦Pθ​ is injective, i.e.:

(2.3)∀θ1,θ2∈Θ,θ1≠θ2  ⟹  Pθ1≠Pθ2\tag{2.3} \forall \theta_1, \theta_2 \in \Theta, \theta_1 \neq \theta_2 \implies \P_{\theta_1} \neq \P_{\theta_2}∀θ1​,θ2​∈Θ,θ1​̸​=θ2​⟹Pθ1​​̸​=Pθ2​​(2.3)

Lecture 4: Parametric Estimation and Confidence Intervals

A statistic is any measurable function of the sample.

An estimator of θ\thetaθ is any statistic whose expression doesn't depend on θ\thetaθ.

An estimator θ^n\ethnθ^n​ of θ\thetaθ is weakly (resp. strongly) consistent if:

(2.4)θ^n→n→∞P  (resp.  a.s.)θ(Pθ)\tag{2.4} \ethn \conv{\P\;(resp.\;a.s.)} \theta \quad (\P_\theta)θ^n​P(resp.a.s.)n→∞​θ(Pθ​)(2.4)

An estimator θ^n\ethnθ^n​ of θ\thetaθ is asymptotically normal if:

(2.5)n(θ^n−θ)→n→∞(d)N(0,σ2)\tag{2.5} \sqrt{n}(\ethn - \theta) \convd \Norm(0, \sigma^2)n​(θ^n​−θ)(d)n→∞​N(0,σ2)(2.5)

The quantity σ2\sigma^2σ2 is called the asymptotic variance of θ^n\ethnθ^n​, noted

(2.6)V(θ^n)=σ2\tag{2.6} V(\ethn) = \sigma^2V(θ^n​)=σ2(2.6)

The bias of an estimator θ^n\ethnθ^n​ of θ\thetaθ is defined as:

(2.7)Bias⁡(θ^n)=E[θ^n]−θ\tag{2.7} \Bias(\ethn) = \E[\ethn] - \thetaBias(θ^n​)=E[θ^n​]−θ(2.7)

If Bias⁡(θ^n)=0\Bias(\ethn) = 0Bias(θ^n​)=0, then we say that θ^n\ethnθ^n​ is unbiased.

The quadratic risk (or risk) of an estimator θ^n\ethnθ^n​ is

(2.8)R(θ^n)=E[(θ^n−θ)2]=V[θ^n]+Bias⁡(θ^n)2\tag{2.8} R(\ethn) = \E\left[(\ethn - \theta)^2\right] = \V[\ethn] + \Bias(\ethn)^2R(θ^n​)=E[(θ^n​−θ)2]=V[θ^n​]+Bias(θ^n​)2(2.8)

Let (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) be a statistical model with Θ⊆R\Theta \subseteq \RΘ⊆R associated with observations X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​, and α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1).

A confidence interval (C.I.) of level 1−α1 - \alpha1−α is any random interval I\mathcal{I}I independent from θ\thetaθ such as:

(2.9)∀θ∈Θ,Pθ[I∋θ]≥1−α\tag{2.9} \forall \theta \in \Theta, \P_\theta[\mathcal{I} \ni \theta] \geq 1 - \alpha∀θ∈Θ,Pθ​[I∋θ]≥1−α(2.9)

A C.I. of asymptotic level 1−α1 - \alpha1−α is any random interval In\mathcal{I}_nIn​ independent from θ\thetaθ such as:

(2.10)∀θ∈Θ,lim⁡n→∞Pθ[In∋θ]≥1−α\tag{2.10} \forall \theta \in \Theta, \limn\P_\theta[\mathcal{I}_n \ni \theta] \geq 1 - \alpha∀θ∈Θ,n→∞lim​Pθ​[In​∋θ]≥1−α(2.10)

Example: X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dBer(p)\Xton \iid \Ber(p)X1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dBer(p). Our estimator is p^n=Xˉn\estn{p} = \bar{X}_np​n​=Xˉn​. From the CLT:

nXˉn−pp(1−p)→n→∞(d)N(0,1)\sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n - p}{\sqrt{p(1-p)}} \convd\Norm(0,1)n​p(1−p)​Xˉn​−p​\convd\Norm(0,1)

Therefore:

\P[np(1−p)∣Xˉn−p∣≤qα/2]=1−α\P\left[\frac{\sqrt{n}}{\sqrt{p(1-p)}}|\bar{X}_n - p| \leq q_{\alpha/2}\right] = 1-\alpha \P[p(1−p)​n​​∣Xˉn​−p∣≤qα/2​]=1−α
\P[[Xˉn−p(1−p)nqα/2,Xˉn+p(1−p)nqα/2]∋p]=1−α\P\left[\left[\bar{X}_n - \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}q_{\alpha/2}, \bar{X}_n + \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}}q_{\alpha/2}\right] \ni p\right] = 1-\alpha\P[[Xˉn​−np(1−p)​​qα/2​,Xˉn​+np(1−p)​​qα/2​]∋p]=1−α

But this is not an asymptotic C.I. because the interval depends on ppp. We have three ways to find an actual confidence inteval:

Convervative bounds:

∀p∈(0,1),p(1−p)≤14  ⟹  Iconv=Xˉn+[−qα/22n,qα/22n]\forall p \in (0, 1), p(1-p) \leq \frac14 \implies \mathcal{I}_{conv} = \bar{X}_n + \left[-\frac{q_{\alpha/2}}{2\sqrt{n}}, \frac{q_{\alpha/2}}{2\sqrt{n}}\right]∀p∈(0,1),p(1−p)≤41​⟹Iconv​=Xˉn​+[−2n​qα/2​​,2n​qα/2​​]

Solve bounds, by solving the quadratic equation in ppp:

(p−Xˉn)2≤qα/22np(1−p)  ⟹  Isolve=[p1,p2](p - \bar{X}_n)^2 \leq \frac{q^2_{\alpha/2}}{n}p(1-p) \implies \mathcal{I}_{solve} = [p_1, p_2](p−Xˉn​)2≤nqα/22​​p(1−p)⟹Isolve​=[p1​,p2​]

Plug-in bounds; as p^n→n→∞a.s.p\estn{p} \convas pp​n​a.s.n→∞​p, we can apply Slutsky's theorem:

nXˉn−pp^n(1−p^n)→n→∞(d)N(0,1)  ⟹  Iplug=Xˉn+qα/2[−p^n(1−p^n)n,p^n(1−p^n)n]\sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n-p}{\sqrt{\estn{p}(1 -\estn{p})}} \convd \Norm(0, 1) \implies \mathcal{I}_{plug} = \bar{X}_n + q_{\alpha/2}\left[-\sqrt{\frac{\estn{p}(1-\estn{p})}{n}}, \sqrt{\frac{\estn{p}(1-\estn{p})}{n}}\right]n​p​n​(1−p​n​)​Xˉn​−p​(d)n→∞​N(0,1)⟹Iplug​=Xˉn​+qα/2​[−np​n​(1−p​n​)​​,np​n​(1−p​n​)​​]

All three intervals verify:

\limn\P[I∋p]≥1−α\limn \P[\mathcal{I} \ni p] \geq 1 - \alpha\limn\P[I∋p]≥1−α

If I\mathcal{I}I is a confidence interval of level α\alphaα, it is also a confidence interval of level β\betaβ for all β≤α\beta \leq \alphaβ≤α.

A confidence interval of level α\alphaα means that if we repeat the experience multiple times, then the real parameter will be in the confidence interval with frequency α\alphaα. It does not mean that the real parameter is in the interval with a certain confidence (as the real parameter is deterministic).

Lecture 5: Delta Method and Confidence Intervals

The Delta Method. Let (Xn)n(X_n)_n(Xn​)n​ be a sequence of r.v. such as

n(Xn−θ)\convd\Norm(0,σ2)\sqrt{n}(X_n - \theta) \convd \Norm(0, \sigma^2)n​(Xn​−θ)\convd\Norm(0,σ2)

for some θ∈R,σ2>0\theta \in \R, \sigma^2 > 0θ∈R,σ2>0. Let g:R→Rg: \R \rightarrow \Rg:R→R continuously differentiable at θ\thetaθ. Then (g(Xn))n(g(X_n))_n(g(Xn​))n​ is asymptotically normal around g(θ)g(\theta)g(θ) and:

(2.11)n(g(Xn)−g(θ))\convd\Norm(0,g′(θ)2σ2)\tag{2.11}\sqrt{n}(g(X_n) - g(\theta)) \convd \Norm(0, g'(\theta)^2\sigma^2)n​(g(Xn​)−g(θ))(d)n→∞​N(0,g′(θ)2σ2)(2.11)

Lecture 6: Introduction to Hypothesis Testing, and Type 1 and Type 2 Errors

Let us consider a sample X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​ of i.i.d r.v. and a statistical model (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​). Let us consider Θ0⨿Θ1=Θ\Theta_0 \amalg \Theta_1 = \ThetaΘ0​⨿Θ1​=Θ.

  • H0:θ∈Θ0H_0: \theta \in \Theta_0H0​:θ∈Θ0​ is called the null hypothesis,
  • H1:θ∈Θ1H_1: \theta \in \Theta_1H1​:θ∈Θ1​ is called the alternative hypothesis.

We are testing H0H_0H0​ against H1H_1H1​ to decide whether to reject H0H_0H0​ by looking for evidence against H0H_0H0​.

H0H_0H0​ and H1H_1H1​ do not play symmetric roles in hypothesis testing: H0H_0H0​ is the default hypothesis when we lack evidence.

A test is a statistic ψ:En→{0,1}\psi : E^n \rightarrow \{0, 1\}ψ:En→{0,1} such as:

  • If ψ(X1,…,Xn)=0\psi(\Xton) = 0ψ(X1​,…,Xn​)=0 then H0H_0H0​ is not rejected,
  • If ψ(X1,…,Xn)=1\psi(\Xton) = 1ψ(X1​,…,Xn​)=1 then H0H_0H0​ is rejected and H1H_1H1​ is accepted.

The rejection region of a test ψ\psiψ is:

(2.12)Rψ={\xx∈En,ψ(\xx)=1}\tag{2.12} R_\psi = \{\xx \in E^n, \psi(\xx) = 1\}Rψ​={\xx∈En,ψ(\xx)=1}(2.12)

The type 1 error of a test ψ\psiψ corresponds to rejecting H0H_0H0​ when it is actually true:

(2.13)\funαψΘ0[0,1]θ\Pθ[ψ(\XX)=1]\tag{2.13} \fun{\alpha_\psi}{\Theta_0}{[0, 1]}{\theta}{\P_\theta[\psi(\XX) = 1]}\funαψ​Θ0​[0,1]θ\Pθ​[ψ(\XX)=1](2.13)

The type 2 error of a test ψ\psiψ corresponds to not rejecting H0H_0H0​ when H1H_1H1​ is actually true:

(2.14)\funβψΘ1[0,1]θ\Pθ[ψ(\XX)=0]\tag{2.14} \fun{\beta_\psi}{\Theta_1}{[0, 1]}{\theta}{\P_\theta[\psi(\XX) = 0]}\funβψ​Θ1​[0,1]θ\Pθ​[ψ(\XX)=0](2.14)

Type 1 and type 2 errors are summaries as follows (RRR is real, TTT is test):

R\TH0H1H0✓1H12✓\begin{array}{ccc}R\char`\\ T & H_0 & H_1 \\ H_0 & \checkmark & 1 \\ H_1 & 2 & \checkmark \end{array}R\TH0​H1​​H0​✓2​H1​1✓​

The power of a test ψ\psiψ is:

(2.15)πψ=inf⁡θ∈Θ1(1−βψ(θ))\tag{2.15} \pi_\psi = \inf_{\theta \in \Theta_1}(1 - \beta_\psi(\theta))πψ​=θ∈Θ1​inf​(1−βψ​(θ))(2.15)

Lecture 7: Hypothesis Testing (Continued): Levels and P-values

A test ψ\psiψ has level α\alphaα if:

(2.16)∀θ∈Θ0,αψ(θ)≤α\tag{2.16} \forall \theta \in \Theta_0, \alpha_\psi(\theta) \leq \alpha∀θ∈Θ0​,αψ​(θ)≤α(2.16)

A test ψ\psiψ has asymptotic level α\alphaα if:

(2.17)∀θ∈Θ0,\limnαψn(θ)≤α\tag{2.17} \forall \theta \in \Theta_0, \limn \alpha_{\psi_n}(\theta) \leq \alpha∀θ∈Θ0​,\limnαψn​​(θ)≤α(2.17)

In general, a test has the form

ψ=\one{Tn>c}\psi = \one\{T_n > c\}ψ=\one{Tn​>c}

for some statistic TnT_nTn​ and threshold ccc. TnT_nTn​ is called the test statistic and the rejection region is Rψ={Tn>c}R_\psi = \{T_n > c\}Rψ​={Tn​>c}.

We have two main types of tests:

  • If H0:θ=θ0H_0: \theta = \theta_0H0​:θ=θ0​ and H1:θ≠θ0H_1: \theta \neq \theta_0H1​:θ̸​=θ0​, it is a two-sided test,
  • If H0:θ≤θ0H_0: \theta \leq \theta_0H0​:θ≤θ0​ and H1:θ>θ0H_1: \theta > \theta_0H1​:θ>θ0​, it is a one-sided test.

Example: Let X1,…,Xn\iidD(μ)X_1, …, X_n \iid \mathcal{D}(\mu)X1​,…,Xn​\iidD(μ) where μ\muμ and σ2\sigma^2σ2 are the expectation and variance of D(μ)\mathcal{D}(\mu)D(μ). Let's consider μ0\mu_0μ0​.

We want to test H0:μ=μ0H_0: \mu = \mu_0H0​:μ=μ0​ against H1:μ≠μ0H_1: \mu \neq \mu_0H1​:μ̸​=μ0​ with asymptotic level α\alphaα.

(2.18)Tn=nμ^n−μ0σ→n→∞(d)N(0,1)\tag{2.18} T_n = \sqrt{n}\frac{\estn{\mu} - \mu_0}{\sigma} \convd \Norm(0, 1)Tn​=n​σμ​n​−μ0​​(d)n→∞​N(0,1)(2.18)

Therefore, if H0H_0H0​ is true, then

P[∣Tn∣>qα/2]→n→∞α\P[|T_n| > q_{\alpha/2}] \conv{} \alphaP[∣Tn​∣>qα/2​]n→∞​α

Let ψα=1{∣Tn∣>qα/2}\psi_\alpha = \one\{|T_n| > q_{\alpha/2}\}ψα​=1{∣Tn​∣>qα/2​}.

Now, we want to test H0:μ≤μ0H_0: \mu \leq \mu_0H0​:μ≤μ0​ and H1:μ>μ0H_1: \mu > \mu_0H1​:μ>μ0​ with asymptotic level α\alphaα. Which value of μ∈Θ0\mu \in \Theta_0μ∈Θ0​ should we consider?

Type 1 error is the function μ↦\Pμ[ψ(\XX)=1]\mu \mapsto \P_\mu[\psi(\XX) = 1]μ↦\Pμ​[ψ(\XX)=1]. To control the level, we need the μ\muμ that maximises this expression over Θ0\Theta_0Θ0​: clearly, this happens for μ=μ0\mu = \mu_0μ=μ0​. Therefore, if H0H_0H0​ is true, then

\Pμ0[Tn>qα]\convα\P_{\mu_0}[T_n > q_\alpha] \conv{} \alpha\Pμ0​​[Tn​>qα​]\convα

If H1:μ<μ0H_1: \mu < \mu_0H1​:μ<μ0​, then we want \Pμ0[Tn<−qα]\P_{\mu_0}[T_n < -q_\alpha]\Pμ0​​[Tn​<−qα​].

The (asymptotic) p-value of a test ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ is the smallest (asymptotic) level α\alphaα at which ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ rejects H0H_0H0​. The p-value is random and depends on the sample.

The golden rule: H0H_0H0​ is rejected by ψα\psi_\alphaψα​ at any asymptotic level α≥p-value⁡(X)\alpha \geq \pval(\XX)α≥p-value(X).

Unit 3: Methods of estimation

Lecture 8: Distance measures between distributions

Let (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) a statistical model, associated with a sample of i.i.d r.v. X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​. We assume the model is well specified, i.e. ∃θ∗∈Θ,X∼Pθ∗\exists \trth \in \Theta, X \sim \P_\trth∃θ∗∈Θ,X∼Pθ∗​. θ∗\trthθ∗ is called the true parameter.

We want to find an estimator θ^n\ethnθ^n​ such that Pθ^n\P_{\ethn}Pθ^n​​ is close to Pθ∗\P_\trthPθ∗​.

The total variation distance between two probability measures P1\P_1P1​ and P2\P_2P2​ is defined as:

(3.1)TV⁡(P1,P2)=max⁡A⊂E∣P1(A)−P2(A)∣\tag{3.1} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \max_{A \subset E}|\P_1(A) - \P_2(A)|TV(P1​,P2​)=A⊂Emax​∣P1​(A)−P2​(A)∣(3.1)

If EEE is discrete, and p1,p2p_1, p_2p1​,p2​ are the PMF associated with P1\P_1P1​ and P2\P_2P2​:

(3.2)TV⁡(P1,P2)=12∑x∈E∣p1(x)−p2(x)∣\tag{3.2} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \frac12\sum_{x\in E}|p_1(x) - p_2(x)|TV(P1​,P2​)=21​x∈E∑​∣p1​(x)−p2​(x)∣(3.2)

If EEE is continuous, and f1,f2f_1, f_2f1​,f2​ are the PDF associated with P1\P_1P1​ and P2\P_2P2​:

(3.3)TV⁡(P1,P2)=12∫E∣f1(x)−f2(x)∣dx\tag{3.3} \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \frac12\int_E|f_1(x) - f_2(x)|dxTV(P1​,P2​)=21​∫E​∣f1​(x)−f2​(x)∣dx(3.3)

Proprieties of the total variation distance:

  • The \TV\TV\TV is symmetric: ∀\P1,\P2,\TV(\P1,\P2)=\TV(\P2,\P1)\forall \P_1, \P_2, \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = \TV(\P_2, \P_1)∀\P1​,\P2​,\TV(\P1​,\P2​)=\TV(\P2​,\P1​)
  • The \TV\TV\TV is positive: ∀\P1,\P2,0≤\TV(\P1,\P2)≤1\forall \P_1, \P_2, 0 \leq \TV(\P_1, \P_2) \leq 1∀\P1​,\P2​,0≤\TV(\P1​,\P2​)≤1
  • The \TV\TV\TV is definite: ∀\P1,\P2,\TV(\P1,\P2)=0  ⟹  \P1=\P2\forall \P_1, \P_2, \TV(\P_1, \P_2) = 0 \implies \P_1 = \P_2∀\P1​,\P2​,\TV(\P1​,\P2​)=0⟹\P1​=\P2​ p.p.
  • The \TV\TV\TV verifies the triangle inequality: ∀\P1,\P2,\P3,\TV(\P1,\P3)≤\TV(\P1,\P2)+\TV(\P2,\P3)\forall \P_1, \P_2, \P_3, \TV(\P_1, \P_3) \leq \TV(\P_1, \P_2) + \TV(\P_2, \P_3)∀\P1​,\P2​,\P3​,\TV(\P1​,\P3​)≤\TV(\P1​,\P2​)+\TV(\P2​,\P3​)

Therefore, TV⁡\TVTV is a distance between probability distributions.

Problem 1: TV⁡\TVTV cannot compare discrete and continuous distributions, which means we cannot trust it to give a reliable estimation of distance between unrelated distributions.

Problem 2: We cannot build an estimator θ↦TV⁡^(Pθ,Pθ∗)\theta \mapsto \widehat{\TV}(\P_\theta, \P_\trth)θ↦TV(Pθ​,Pθ∗​) as we do not know θ∗\trthθ∗.

Hence we need another "distance" between distributions. The Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between two probability distributions P1,P2\P_1, \P_2P1​,P2​ is defined as:

(3.4)KL⁡(P1,P2)={∑x∈Ep1(x)ln⁡p1(x)p2(x)if E is discrete∫Ef1(x)ln⁡f1(x)f2(x)dxif E is continuous\tag{3.4} \KL(\P_1, \P_2)= \begin{cases}\displaystyle\sum_{x\in E}p_1(x)\ln\frac{p_1(x)}{p_2(x)} & \text{if }E\text{ is discrete} \\ \displaystyle \int_Ef_1(x)\ln\frac{f_1(x)}{f_2(x)}dx & \text{if }E\text{ is continuous}\end{cases}KL(P1​,P2​)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​x∈E∑​p1​(x)lnp2​(x)p1​(x)​∫E​f1​(x)lnf2​(x)f1​(x)​dx​if E is discreteif E is continuous​(3.4)

Proprieties of the KL⁡\KLKL divergence:

  • In general, \KL(\P1,\P2)≠\KL(\P2,\P1)\KL(\P_1, \P_2) \neq \KL(\P_2, \P_1)\KL(\P1​,\P2​)̸​=\KL(\P2​,\P1​)
  • The \KL\KL\KL is positive: ∀\P1,\P2,\KL(\P1,\P2)≥0\forall \P_1, \P_2, \KL(\P_1, \P_2) \geq 0∀\P1​,\P2​,\KL(\P1​,\P2​)≥0
  • The \KL\KL\KL is definite: ∀\P1,\P2,\KL(\P1,\P2)=0  ⟹  \P1=\P2\forall \P_1, \P_2, \KL(\P_1, \P_2) = 0 \implies \P_1 = \P_2∀\P1​,\P2​,\KL(\P1​,\P2​)=0⟹\P1​=\P2​
  • In general, \KL(\P1,\P3)̸≤\KL(\P1,\P2)+\KL(\P2,\P3)\KL(\P_1, \P_3) \not\leq \KL(\P_1, \P_2) + \KL(\P_2, \P_3)\KL(\P1​,\P3​)̸​≤\KL(\P1​,\P2​)+\KL(\P2​,\P3​)

KL⁡\KLKL is not a distance, it's a divergence. But we still have that θ∗\trthθ∗ is the only minimizer of θ↦KL⁡(Pθ∗,Pθ)\theta \mapsto \KL(\P_\trth, \P_\theta)θ↦KL(Pθ∗​,Pθ​).

Lecture 9: Maximum Likelihood Estimation

KL⁡(Pθ∗,Pθ)=Eθ∗[ln⁡fθ∗(X)fθ(X)]=Eθ∗[ln⁡fθ∗(X)]−Eθ∗[ln⁡fθ(X)]\begin{aligned}\KL(\P_\trth, \P_\theta) &= \E_\trth\left[\ln\frac{f_\trth(X)}{f_\theta(X)}\right] \\ &= \E_\trth[\ln f_\trth(X)] - \E_\trth[\ln f_\theta(X)]\end{aligned}KL(Pθ∗​,Pθ​)​=Eθ∗​[lnfθ​(X)fθ∗​(X)​]=Eθ∗​[lnfθ∗​(X)]−Eθ∗​[lnfθ​(X)]​

Therefore, by the LLN the KL⁡\KLKL divergence can be estimated by taking the average of ln⁡fθ(Xi)\ln f_\theta(X_i)lnfθ​(Xi​):

KL⁡^(Pθ∗,Pθ)=constant−1n∑i=1nln⁡fθ(Xi)\widehat{\KL}(\P_\trth, \P_\theta) = \text{constant} - \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n\ln f_\theta(X_i)KL(Pθ∗​,Pθ​)=constant−n1​i=1∑n​lnfθ​(Xi​)

Therefore:

argmin⁡θ∈ΘKL⁡^(Pθ∗,Pθ)=argmin⁡θ∈Θ−1n∑i=1nln⁡fθ(Xi)=argmax⁡θ∈Θln⁡∏i=1nfθ(Xi)=argmax⁡θ∈Θ∏i=1nfθ(Xi)\begin{aligned} \argmin{\theta \in \Theta}\widehat{\KL}(\P_\trth, \P_\theta) &= \argmin{\theta \in \Theta} -\frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n\ln f_\theta(X_i) \\ &= \argmax{\theta \in \Theta}\ln\prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(X_i) \\ &= \argmax{\theta \in \Theta}\prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(X_i) \end{aligned}θ∈Θargmin​KL(Pθ∗​,Pθ​)​=θ∈Θargmin​−n1​i=1∑n​lnfθ​(Xi​)=θ∈Θargmax​lni=1∏n​fθ​(Xi​)=θ∈Θargmax​i=1∏n​fθ​(Xi​)​

This is the maximum likelihood principle.

Let (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) be a statistical model associated with a sample of i.i.d r.v. X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​. The likelihood of the model is the function:

(3.5)Ln:En×Θ→[0,1](X1,…,Xn,θ)↦{∏i=1npθ(xi)if E is discrete∏i=1nfθ(xi)if E is continous\tag{3.5}\fun{L_n}{E^n \times \Theta}{[0, 1]}{(\Xton, \theta)}{\begin{cases} \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^np_\theta(x_i) & \text{if }E\text{ is discrete} \\ \displaystyle \prod_{i=1}^nf_\theta(x_i) & \text{if }E\text{ is continous} \end{cases}}Ln​​:​En×Θ(X1​,…,Xn​,θ)​→↦​[0,1]⎩⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎧​i=1∏n​pθ​(xi​)i=1∏n​fθ​(xi​)​if E is discreteif E is continous​​(3.5)

The maximum likelihood estimator of θ\thetaθ is defined as:

(3.6)θ^nMLE=argmax⁡θ∈ΘLn(X1,…,Xn,θ)\tag{3.6} \ethn^{MLE} = \argmax{\theta \in \Theta} L_n(\Xton, \theta)θ^nMLE​=θ∈Θargmax​Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​,θ)(3.6)

In practice, we often use the log-likelihood ℓn(X1,…,Xn,θ)=ln⁡Ln(X1,…,Xn,θ)\ell_n(\Xton, \theta) = \ln L_n(\Xton, \theta)ℓn​(X1​,…,Xn​,θ)=lnLn​(X1​,…,Xn​,θ).

A function twice differentiable h:Θ⊆R→Rh : \Theta \subseteq \R \rightarrow \Rh:Θ⊆R→R is concave (resp. strictly) if

(3.7)∀θ∈Θ,h′′(θ)≤0(resp. <0)\tag{3.7} \forall \theta \in \Theta, h''(\theta) \leq 0 \quad\text{(resp. }< 0\text{)}∀θ∈Θ,h′′(θ)≤0(resp. <0)(3.7)

hhh is convex (resp. strictly) if −h-h−h is concave (resp. strictly).

A con-v-ex function is shaped like a v.

Let h:Θ⊆Rd→Rh: \Theta \subseteq \R^d \rightarrow \Rh:Θ⊆Rd→R be a multivariate function. The gradient vector of hhh is:

(3.8)∇h(θ)=(∂h∂θ1(θ)⋮∂h∂θd(θ))\tag{3.8} \nabla h(\tth) = \begin{pmatrix}\displaystyle \diff{h}{\theta_1}(\tth) \\ \displaystyle \vdots \\ \displaystyle \diff{h}{\theta_d}(\tth)\end{pmatrix}∇h(θ)=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∂θ1​∂h​(θ)⋮∂θd​∂h​(θ)​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​(3.8)

The Hessian matrix of hhh is:

(3.9)Hh(θ)=(∂2h∂θ12(θ)⋯∂2h∂θ1∂θd(θ)⋮⋱⋮∂2h∂θd∂θ1(θ)⋯∂2h∂θd2(θ))∈Rd×d\tag{3.9} \HH h(\tth) = \begin{pmatrix} \displaystyle \diffk{h}{\theta_1}{2}(\tth) & \cdots & \displaystyle \diffd{h}{\theta_1}{\theta_d}(\tth) \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \displaystyle \diffd{h}{\theta_d}{\theta_1}(\tth) & \cdots & \displaystyle \diffk{h}{\theta_d}{2}(\tth) \\ \end{pmatrix} \in \R^{d\times d}Hh(θ)=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​∂θ12​∂2h​(θ)⋮∂θd​∂θ1​∂2h​(θ)​⋯⋱⋯​∂θ1​∂θd​∂2h​(θ)⋮∂θd2​∂2h​(θ)​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​∈Rd×d(3.9)

Therefore, hhh is concave (resp. strictly) if

(3.10)∀x∈Rd∖{0},θ∈Θ,xTHh(θ)x≤0(resp. <0)\tag{3.10} \forall \xx \in \R^d \setminus \{\zz\}, \tth \in \Theta, \xx^T\HH h(\tth)\xx \leq 0 \quad\text{(resp. }< 0\text{)}∀x∈Rd∖{0},θ∈Θ,xTHh(θ)x≤0(resp. <0)(3.10)

If hhh is strictly concave and has a maximum, then this maximum is unique and is reached for

(3.11){h′(θ)=0if Θ⊆R∇h(θ)=0if Θ⊆Rd\tag{3.11} \begin{cases} h'(\theta) = 0 & \text{if }\Theta \subseteq \R \\ \nabla h(\tth) = \zz & \text{if }\Theta \subseteq \R^d \end{cases}{h′(θ)=0∇h(θ)=0​if Θ⊆Rif Θ⊆Rd​(3.11)

Lecture 10: Consistency of MLE, Covariance Matrices, and Multivariate Statistics

Under mild regularity conditions, we have

(3.12)θ^nMLE→n→∞Pθ∗\tag{3.12} \ethn^{MLE} \convp \trthθ^nMLE​Pn→∞​θ∗(3.12)

Notably if the model is well specified.

In general, when θ∈Rd\theta \in \R^dθ∈Rd, the coordinates are not independent. The covariance between two random variables XXX and YYY is defined as:

(3.13)\Cov(X,Y)=\E[(X−\E[X])(Y−\E[Y])]=\E[XY]−\E[X]\E[Y]=\E[X(Y−\E[Y])]\tag{3.13} \begin{aligned} \Cov(X, Y) &= \E[(X - \E[X])(Y - \E[Y])] \\ &= \E[XY] - \E[X]\E[Y] \\ &= \E[X(Y - \E[Y])] \end{aligned}\Cov(X,Y)​=\E[(X−\E[X])(Y−\E[Y])]=\E[XY]−\E[X]\E[Y]=\E[X(Y−\E[Y])]​(3.13)

Properties:

(3.14)\Cov(X,X)=\V(X)\tag{3.14} \Cov(X, X) = \V(X)\Cov(X,X)=\V(X)(3.14)
(3.15)\Cov(X,Y)=\Cov(Y,X)\tag{3.15} \Cov(X, Y) = \Cov(Y, X)\Cov(X,Y)=\Cov(Y,X)(3.15)

If XXX and YYY are independent, then \Cov(X,Y)=0\Cov(X, Y) = 0\Cov(X,Y)=0 and \E[XY]=\E[X]\E[Y]\E[XY] = \E[X]\E[Y]\E[XY]=\E[X]\E[Y].

Attention: the converse is not true; if \Cov(X,Y)=0\Cov(X, Y) = 0\Cov(X,Y)=0, XXX and YYY may be dependent.

If \XX=(X(1),…,X(d))T∈Rd\XX = (X^{(1)}, \ldots, X^{(d)})^T \in \R^d\XX=(X(1),…,X(d))T∈Rd, then the covariance matrix of the vector is given by:

(3.16)\SSigma=\CCov(\XX)=\E[(\XX−\E[\XX])(\XX−\E[\XX])T]∈Rd×d\tag{3.16} \SSigma = \CCov(\XX) = \E[(\XX - \E[\XX])(\XX - \E[\XX])^T] \in \R^{d \times d}\SSigma=\CCov(\XX)=\E[(\XX−\E[\XX])(\XX−\E[\XX])T]∈Rd×d(3.16)

Its terms are:

\SSigmai,j=\Cov(X(i),X(j))\SSigma_{i,j} = \Cov(X^{(i)}, X^{(j)})\SSigmai,j​=\Cov(X(i),X(j))

Proprieties:

(3.17)\CCov(A\XX+B)=\CCov(A\XX)=A\CCov(\XX)AT\tag{3.17} \CCov(A\XX + B) = \CCov(A\XX) = A\CCov(\XX)A^T\CCov(A\XX+B)=\CCov(A\XX)=A\CCov(\XX)AT(3.17)

The Multivariate Central Limit Theorem, let \XX1,…,\XXn∈Rd\XX_1, \ldots, \XX_n \in \R^d\XX1​,…,\XXn​∈Rd i.i.d copies of \XX\XX\XX such that \E[\XX]=\mmu\E[\XX] = \mmu\E[\XX]=\mmu and \CCov(\XX)=\SSigma\CCov(\XX) = \SSigma\CCov(\XX)=\SSigma. Then:

(3.18)n(\XXˉn−\mmu)\convd\Normd(\zz,\SSigma)\tag{3.18} \sqrt{n}(\bar{\XX}_n - \mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, \SSigma)n​(\XXˉ​n​−\mmu)\convd\Normd​(\zz,\SSigma)(3.18)

Equivalently,

n\SSigma−1/2(\XXˉn−\mmu)\convd\Normd(\zz,Id)\sqrt{n}\SSigma^{-1/2}(\bar{\XX}_n - \mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, I_d)n​Σ−1/2(Xˉn​−μ)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,Id​)

The Multivariate Delta Method, let (Tn)n∈(Rd)N(\TT_n)_n \in (\R^d)^\N(Tn​)n​∈(Rd)N be a sequence of random vectors such that

n(Tn−θ)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,Σ)\sqrt{n}(\TT_n - \tth) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, \SSigma)n​(Tn​−θ)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,Σ)

with θ∈Rd,Σ∈Rd×d\tth \in \R^d, \SSigma \in \R^{d\times d}θ∈Rd,Σ∈Rd×d. Let g:Rd→Rk\bm{g}: \R^d \rightarrow \R^kg:Rd→Rk be continuously differentiable in θ\tthθ. Then:

(3.19)n(g(Tn)−g(θ))→n→∞(d)Nk(0,∇g(θ)TΣ∇g(θ))\tag{3.19} \sqrt{n}(\bm{g}(\TT_n) - \bm{g}(\tth)) \convd \Norm_k(\zz, \nabla \bm{g}(\tth)^T\SSigma\nabla \bm{g}(\tth))n​(g(Tn​)−g(θ))(d)n→∞​Nk​(0,∇g(θ)TΣ∇g(θ))(3.19)

where

∇g(θ)=(∂gj∂θi)i,j=(∇g1(θ),⋯ ,∇gk(θ))\nabla \bm{g}(\tth) = \left(\diff{g_j}{\theta_i}\right)_{i, j} = \left(\nabla g_1(\tth), \cdots,\nabla g_k(\tth)\right)∇g(θ)=(∂θi​∂gj​​)i,j​=(∇g1​(θ),⋯,∇gk​(θ))

Lecture 11: Fisher Information, Asymptotic Normality of MLE; Methods of Moments

Let (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) be a statistical model with Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd, and X\XXX an associated random variable. With

ℓ(θ)=ln⁡L1(X,θ)\ell(\tth) = \ln L_1(\XX, \tth)ℓ(θ)=lnL1​(X,θ)

The Fisher Information of the model is defined as:

(3.20)I:θ↦E[∇ℓ(θ)∇ℓ(θ)T]−E[∇ℓ(θ)]E[∇ℓ(θ)]T\tag{3.20} I : \tth \mapsto \E[\nabla\ell(\tth)\nabla\ell(\tth)^T] - \E[\nabla\ell(\tth)]\E[\nabla\ell(\tth)]^TI:θ↦E[∇ℓ(θ)∇ℓ(θ)T]−E[∇ℓ(θ)]E[∇ℓ(θ)]T(3.20)

Under some regularity conditions, we have that:

(3.21)I(θ)=−E[Hℓ(θ)]\tag{3.21} I(\tth) = - \E[\HH\ell(\tth)]I(θ)=−E[Hℓ(θ)](3.21)

If Θ⊆R\Theta \subseteq \RΘ⊆R, we have:

(3.22)I(θ)=V[ℓ′(θ)]=−E[ℓ′′(θ)]\tag{3.22} I(\theta) = \V[\ell'(\theta)] = -\E[\ell''(\theta)]I(θ)=V[ℓ′(θ)]=−E[ℓ′′(θ)](3.22)

Asymptotic normality of the MLE. Let θ∗∈Θ\trtth \in \Thetaθ∗∈Θ be the true parameter. If we have the following:

  • θ∗\trtthθ∗ is identifiable,
  • ∀θ∈Θ\forall \tth \in \Theta∀θ∈Θ, the support of Pθ\P_\thetaPθ​ does not depend on θ\thetaθ,
  • θ∗\trtthθ∗ is not on the boundary of Θ\ThetaΘ,
  • I(θ)I(\tth)I(θ) is invertible in a neighborhood of θ∗\trtthθ∗,
  • A few more technical conditions,

then θ^nMLE\etthn^{MLE}θ^nMLE​ satisfies:

(3.23)θ^nMLE→n→∞Pθ∗[Pθ∗]\tag{3.23} \etthn^{MLE} \convp \trtth \quad [\P_{\trtth}]θ^nMLE​Pn→∞​θ∗[Pθ∗​](3.23)
(3.24)n(θ^nMLE−θ∗)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,I(θ∗)−1)[Pθ∗]\tag{3.24} \sqrt{n}(\etthn^{MLE} - \trtth) \convd \Norm_d(0, I(\trtth)^{-1}) \quad [\P_{\trtth}]n​(θ^nMLE​−θ∗)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,I(θ∗)−1)[Pθ∗​](3.24)

Let X1,…,Xn\XX_1, …, \XX_nX1​,…,Xn​ be an i.i.d sample associated with a statistical model (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​), with E⊆RE \subseteq \RE⊆R and Θ⊆Rd\Theta \subseteq \R^dΘ⊆Rd. The population moments are:

(3.25)∀1≤k≤d,mk(θ)=Eθ[Xk]\tag{3.25} \forall 1 \leq k \leq d, m_k(\tth) = \E_\tth[X^k]∀1≤k≤d,mk​(θ)=Eθ​[Xk](3.25)

And the empirical moments are:

(3.26)∀1≤k≤d,m^k=Xnk‾=1n∑i=1nXik\tag{3.26} \forall 1 \leq k \leq d, \hat{m}_k = \overline{X^k_n} = \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^nX_i^k∀1≤k≤d,m^k​=Xnk​​=n1​i=1∑n​Xik​(3.26)

From the LLN, we have

(3.27)(m^1,…,m^d)→n→∞P/a.s.(m1(θ),…,md(θ))\tag{3.27} (\hat{m}_1, \ldots, \hat{m}_d) \conv{\P / a.s.} (m_1(\tth), \ldots, m_d(\tth))(m^1​,…,m^d​)P/a.s.n→∞​(m1​(θ),…,md​(θ))(3.27)

Let

M:Θ→Rdθ↦M(θ)=(m1(θ),…,nd(θ))\fun{M}{\Theta}{\R^d}{\tth}{M(\tth) = (m_1(\tth), \ldots, n_d(\tth))}M​:​Θθ​→↦​RdM(θ)=(m1​(θ),…,nd​(θ))​

Then if MMM is injective, θ=M−1(m1(θ),…,md(θ))\tth = M^{-1}(m_1(\tth), \ldots, m_d(\tth))θ=M−1(m1​(θ),…,md​(θ))

The moment estimator of θ\tthθ, if it exists, is defined as

(3.28)θ^nMM=M−1(m^1,…,m^d)\tag{3.28} \etthn^{MM} = M^{-1}(\hat m_1, \ldots, \hat m_d)θ^nMM​=M−1(m^1​,…,m^d​)(3.28)

Let M^=(m^1,…,m^d)\hat M = (\hat m_1, \ldots, \hat m_d)M^=(m^1​,…,m^d​). Let Σ(θ)=Cov⁡θ(X,X2,…,Xd)\SSigma(\tth) = \CCov_\tth(X, X^2, \ldots, X^d)Σ(θ)=Covθ​(X,X2,…,Xd). Let us assume M−1M^{-1}M−1 is continuously differentiable at M(θ)M(\tth)M(θ).

We can generalize the method of moments to any set of functions g1,…,gd:R→Rg_1, \ldots, g_d : R \rightarrow \Rg1​,…,gd​:R→R well chosen, by defining mk(θ)=Eθ[gk(X)]m_k(\tth) = \E_\tth[g_k(X)]mk​(θ)=Eθ​[gk​(X)] and Σ(θ)=Cov⁡θ(g1(X),…,gk(X))\SSigma(\tth) = \CCov_\tth(g_1(X), \ldots, g_k(X))Σ(θ)=Covθ​(g1​(X),…,gk​(X)).

The generalized method of moments yields, by applying the CLT and the Delta method:

(3.29)n(θ^nMM−θ)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,Γ(θ))\tag{3.29} \sqrt{n}(\etthn^{MM} - \theta) \convd\Norm_d(\zz, \Gamma(\tth))n​(θ^nMM​−θ)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,Γ(θ))(3.29)

where

Γ(θ)=[∇M−1(M(θ))]TΣ(θ)[∇M−1(M(θ))]\Gamma(\tth) = \left[\nabla M^{-1}(M(\tth))\right]^T\SSigma(\tth)\left[\nabla M^{-1}(M(\tth))\right]Γ(θ)=[∇M−1(M(θ))]TΣ(θ)[∇M−1(M(θ))]

The MLEMLEMLE is more accurate than the MMMMMM, the MLEMLEMLE still gives good results if the model is mis-specified, however the MMMMMM is easier to compute and the MLEMLEMLE can be intractable sometimes.

Lecture 12: M-Estimation

Let X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dP\Xton \iid \PX1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dP on a sample space E⊆RdE \subseteq \R^dE⊆Rd.

The goal is to estimate some parameter μ∗\true\mmuμ∗ associated with P\PP. We find a function ρ:E×M→R\rho : E \times \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \Rρ:E×M→R, where M\mathcal{M}M is the parameter set for μ∗\true\mmuμ∗, such that:

Q(μ)=E[ρ(X,μ)]\mathcal{Q}(\mmu) = \E[\rho(\XX, \mmu)]Q(μ)=E[ρ(X,μ)]

verifies

(3.30)μ∗=argmin⁡μ∈MQ(μ)\tag{3.30} \true\mu = \argmin{\mu \in \mathcal{M}}\mathcal{Q}(\mu)μ∗=μ∈Margmin​Q(μ)(3.30)

For example:

  • if ρ(\xx,\mmu)=∥\xx−\mmu∥22\rho(\xx, \mmu) = \|\xx - \mmu\|_2^2ρ(\xx,\mmu)=∥\xx−\mmu∥22​, then \true\mmu=\E[\XX]\true\mmu = \E[\XX]\true\mmu=\E[\XX].
  • if ρ(x,μ)=∣x−μ∣\rho(x, \mu) = |x - \mu|ρ(x,μ)=∣x−μ∣, then \trueμ=\Med(X)\true\mu = \Med{}(X)\trueμ=\Med(X).

Let α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1). We define the check functions:

\funCαRRx{−(1−α)xif x<0αxif x≥0\fun{C_\alpha}{\R}{\R}{x}{\begin{cases} -(1-\alpha)x & \text{if } x < 0 \\ \alpha x & \text{if } x \geq 0 \end{cases}}Cα​​:​Rx​→↦​R{−(1−α)xαx​if x<0if x≥0​​

If (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​) is a statistical model associated with the data, M=Θ\mathcal{M} = \ThetaM=Θ, and ρ=−ℓ1\rho = -\ell_1ρ=−ℓ1​ the negative log-likelihood, then

(3.31)μ∗=θ∗\tag{3.31}\true\mmu = \trtthμ∗=θ∗(3.31)

where P=Pθ∗\P = \P_\trtthP=Pθ∗​. As such, the MLEMLEMLE estimator is an M-estimator.

Let

J(μ)=HQ(μ)J(\mmu) = \HH Q(\mmu)J(μ)=HQ(μ)

under some regularity conditions,

J(μ)=E[∂2ρ∂μ∂μT(X,μ)]J(\mmu) = \E\left[\diffd{\rho}{\mmu}{\mmu^T}(X, \mmu)\right]J(μ)=E[∂μ∂μT∂2ρ​(X,μ)]

Let

K(μ)=Cov⁡[∇μρ(X,μ)]K(\mmu) = \CCov\left[\nabla_\mmu\rho(X, \mmu)\right]K(μ)=Cov[∇μ​ρ(X,μ)]

In the case of the log-likelihood, we have J(θ)=K(θ)=I(θ)J(\tth) = K(\tth) = I(\tth)J(θ)=K(θ)=I(θ).

Let μ∗∈M\true\mmu \in \mathcal{M}μ∗∈M be the true parameter. If we have:

  • \true\mmu\true\mmu\true\mmu is the only minimizer of Q\mathcal{Q}Q,
  • J(\mmu)J(\mmu)J(\mmu) is invertible for all \mmu∈M\mmu \in \mathcal{M}\mmu∈M,
  • A few more technical conditions,

then μ^n\estn{\mmu}μ​n​ satisfies:

(3.32)μ^n→n→∞Pμ∗\tag{3.32} \estn{\mmu} \convp \true\mmuμ​n​Pn→∞​μ∗(3.32)
(3.33)n(μ^n−μ∗)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,J−1(μ∗)TK(μ∗)J−1(μ∗))\tag{3.33} \sqrt{n}(\estn{\mmu} - \true\mmu) \convd \Norm_d(\zz, J^{-1}(\true\mmu)^TK(\true\mmu)J^{-1}(\true\mmu))n​(μ​n​−μ∗)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,J−1(μ∗)TK(μ∗)J−1(μ∗))(3.33)

Unit 4: Hypothesis testing

Lecture 13: Chi Squared Distribution, T-Test

The chi-squared (χ2\chi^2χ2) distribution: let d∈N∗d \in \N^*d∈N∗. the χd2\chi^2_dχd2​ distribution with ddd degrees of freedom is the law of the random variable

(4.1)Z12+…+Zd2∼χd2\tag{4.1} Z_1^2 + \ldots + Z_d^2 \sim \chi^2_dZ12​+…+Zd2​∼χd2​(4.1)

where Z1,…,Zd∼i.i.dN(0,1)Z_1, \ldots, Z_d \iid \Norm(0, 1)Z1​,…,Zd​∼i.i.dN(0,1).

  • If Z∼Nd(0,Id)Z \sim \Norm_d(0, I_d)Z∼Nd​(0,Id​), then ∥Z∥22∼χd2\|Z\|_2^2 \sim \chi^2_d∥Z∥22​∼χd2​.
  • χ22=Exp(1/2)\chi^2_2 = \Exp(1/2)χ22​=Exp(1/2).

Proprieties: let V∼χd2V \sim \chi^2_dV∼χd2​.

(4.2)E[V]=d,V[V]=2d\tag{4.2} \E[V] = d, \quad \V[V] = 2dE[V]=d,V[V]=2d(4.2)

Cochran's Theorem: let X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dN(μ,σ2)\Xton \iid \Norm(\mu, \sigma^2)X1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dN(μ,σ2). Let

Sn=1n∑i=1n(Xi−Xˉn)2=1n∑i=1nXi2−Xˉn2S_n = \frac1n \sum_{i=1}^n(X_i - \bar{X}_n)^2 = \frac1n \sum_{i=1}^nX_i^2 - \bar{X}_n^2Sn​=n1​i=1∑n​(Xi​−Xˉn​)2=n1​i=1∑n​Xi2​−Xˉn2​

Be the sample variance. Then:

(4.3)∀n∈N,Xˉn⊥​​​​⊥SnandnSnσ2∼χn−12\tag{4.3}\forall n \in \N, \bar{X}_n \indep S_n \quad \text{and} \quad \frac{nS_n}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{n-1}∀n∈N,Xˉn​⊥⊥Sn​andσ2nSn​​∼χn−12​(4.3)

We often prefer the unbiased sample variance:

S~n=1n−1∑i=1n(Xi−Xˉn)2=nn−1Sn\tilde{S}_n = \frac1{n-1}\sum_{i=1}^n(X_i - \bar{X}_n)^2 = \frac{n}{n-1}S_nS~n​=n−11​i=1∑n​(Xi​−Xˉn​)2=n−1n​Sn​

Which verifies E[S~n]=σ2\E[\tilde{S}_n] = \sigma^2E[S~n​]=σ2. In this case, we have instead (n−1)S~nσ2∼χn−12\frac{(n-1)\tilde{S}_n}{\sigma^2} \sim \chi^2_{n-1}σ2(n−1)S~n​​∼χn−12​.

Student's T Distribution: let d∈N∗d \in \N^*d∈N∗. The Student's T Distribution tdt_dtd​ with ddd degrees of freedom is the law of the random variable

(4.4)ZVd∼td\tag{4.4} \frac{Z}{\displaystyle \sqrt{\frac{V}d}} \sim t_ddV​​Z​∼td​(4.4)

where Z∼N(0,1),V∼χd2Z \sim \Norm(0, 1), V \sim \chi^2_dZ∼N(0,1),V∼χd2​ and Z⊥​​​​⊥VZ \indep VZ⊥⊥V.

Student's T test (one sample, two-sided): let X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dN(μ,σ2)\Xton \iid \Norm(\mu, \sigma^2)X1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dN(μ,σ2). We want to test H0:μ=μ0=0H_0: \mu = \mu_0 = 0H0​:μ=μ0​=0 against H1:μ≠0H_1: \mu \neq 0H1​:μ̸​=0. We define the test statistic as:

(4.5)Tn=XˉnS~nn=nXˉn−μ0σS~nσ2\tag{4.5}T_n = \frac{\bar{X}_n}{\displaystyle \sqrt{\frac{\tilde{S}_n}n}} = \frac{\displaystyle \sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n - \mu_0}{\sigma}}{\displaystyle \sqrt{\frac{\tilde{S}_n}{\sigma^2}}}Tn​=nS~n​​​Xˉn​​=σ2S~n​​​n​σXˉn​−μ0​​​(4.5)

Since nXˉn−μ0σ∼N(0,1)\sqrt{n}\frac{\bar{X}_n - \mu_0}{\sigma} \sim \Norm(0, 1)n​σXˉn​−μ0​​∼N(0,1) under H0H_0H0​ and S~nσ2∼1n−1χn−12\frac{\tilde{S}_n}{\sigma^2} \sim \frac1{n-1}\chi^2_{n-1}σ2S~n​​∼n−11​χn−12​ are independent by Cochran's Theorem,

Tn∼tn−1T_n \sim t_{n-1}Tn​∼tn−1​

The non-asymptotic Student's test is therefore written, at level α\alphaα:

ψα=1{∣Tn∣>qα/2(tn−1)}\psi_\alpha = \one\{|T_n| > q_{\alpha/2}(t_{n-1})\}ψα​=1{∣Tn​∣>qα/2​(tn−1​)}

Student's T test (one sample, one-sided): if instead we have H0:μ=μ0=0H_0: \mu = \mu_0 = 0H0​:μ=μ0​=0 and H1:μ>0H_1: \mu > 0H1​:μ>0, the test is written, at level α\alphaα:

ψα=1{Tn>qα(tn−1)}\psi_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha(t_{n-1})\}ψα​=1{Tn​>qα​(tn−1​)}

Student's T test (two samples, two-sided): let X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dN(μX,σX2)\Xton \iid \Norm(\mu_X, \sigma^2_X)X1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dN(μX​,σX2​) and Y1,…,Ym∼i.i.dN(μY,σY2)Y_1, \ldots, Y_m \iid \Norm(\mu_Y, \sigma^2_Y)Y1​,…,Ym​∼i.i.dN(μY​,σY2​). We want to test H0:μX=μYH_0: \mu_X = \mu_YH0​:μX​=μY​ against H1:μX≠μYH_1: \mu_X \neq \mu_YH1​:μX​̸​=μY​. The test statistic is written:

(4.6)Tn,m=Xˉn−Yˉmσ2^Xn+σ2^Ym∼\tag{4.6} T_{n, m} = \frac{\bar{X}_n - \bar{Y}_m}{\displaystyle \sqrt{\frac{\est{\sigma^2}_X}n + \frac{\est{\sigma^2}_Y}m}} \simTn,m​=nσ2X​​+mσ2Y​​​Xˉn​−Yˉm​​∼(4.6)

Welch-Satterthwaite formula: Tn,m∼tNT_{n, m} \sim t_NTn,m​∼tN​ with

(4.7)N=(σ2^Xn+σ2^Ym)2σ2^X2n2(n−1)+σ2^Y2m2(m−1)≥min⁡(n,m)\tag{4.7} N = \frac{\displaystyle \left(\frac{\est{\sigma^2}_X}n + \frac{\est{\sigma^2}_Y}m\right)^2}{\displaystyle \frac{\est{\sigma^2}^2_X}{n^2(n-1)} + \frac{\est{\sigma^2}^2_Y}{m^2(m-1)}} \geq \min(n, m)N=n2(n−1)σ2X2​​+m2(m−1)σ2Y2​​(nσ2X​​+mσ2Y​​)2​≥min(n,m)(4.7)

NNN should always be rounded down.

Pros and cons of the T test:

  • Non-asymptotic and can be run on small samples, and can also be seemlessly applied for large samples.
  • The samples must be Gaussian.

Lecture 14: Wald's Test, Likelihood Ratio Test, and Implicit Hypothesis Testing

Wald's Test: let X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​ i.i.d samples with a statistical model (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​), with Θ⊆Rd,d≥1\Theta \subseteq \R^d, d \geq 1Θ⊆Rd,d≥1. Let θ∗\trtthθ∗ be the true parameter and θ0∈Θ\tth_0 \in \Thetaθ0​∈Θ. We want to test H0:θ∗=θ0H_0: \trtth = \tth_0H0​:θ∗=θ0​ against H1:θ∗≠θ0H_1: \trtth \neq \tth_0H1​:θ∗̸​=θ0​. Let θ^nMLE\etthn^{MLE}θ^nMLE​ be the maximum likelihood estimator, assuming the conditions are satisfied. Under H0H_0H0​, using Slutsky:

nI(θ0)1/2nI(θ∗)1/2nI(θ^nMLE)1/2}(θ^nMLE−θ0)→n→∞(d)Nd(0,Id)\left.\begin{array}{r} \sqrt{n}I(\tth_0)^{1/2} \\ \sqrt{n}I(\trtth)^{1/2} \\ \sqrt{n}I(\etthn^{MLE})^{1/2}\end{array}\right\}\left(\etthn^{MLE} - \tth_0\right) \convd \Norm_d(0, I_d)n​I(θ0​)1/2n​I(θ∗)1/2n​I(θ^nMLE​)1/2​⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​(θ^nMLE​−θ0​)(d)n→∞​Nd​(0,Id​)

Hence, by taking the 2-norm, we have the Wald's test statistic:

(4.8)Tn=n(θ^nMLE−θ0)TI(θ^nMLE)(θ^nMLE−θ0)→n→∞(d)χd2\tag{4.8}T_n = n\left(\etthn^{MLE} - \tth_0\right)^TI\left(\etthn^{MLE}\right)\left(\etthn^{MLE} - \tth_0\right) \convd \chi^2_dTn​=n(θ^nMLE​−θ0​)TI(θ^nMLE​)(θ^nMLE​−θ0​)(d)n→∞​χd2​(4.8)

The corresponding test with level α\alphaα is:

ψα=1{Tn>qα(χd2)}\psi_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha(\chi^2_d)\}ψα​=1{Tn​>qα​(χd2​)}

Wald's test is also valid for a one-sided test, but is less powerful.

Likelihood ratio test: let r∈[​[0,d]​]r \in \lb 0, d \rbr∈[[0,d]]. Let θ0=(θr+10,…,θd0)T∈Rd−r\tth_0 = (\theta^0_{r+1}, \ldots, \theta^0_d)^T \in \R^{d-r}θ0​=(θr+10​,…,θd0​)T∈Rd−r. Let us suppose the null hypothesis is given by:

H0:(θr+1,…,θd)T=θr+1…d=θ0H_0: (\theta_{r+1}, \ldots, \theta_d)^T = \tth_{r+1\ldots d} = \tth_0H0​:(θr+1​,…,θd​)T=θr+1…d​=θ0​

Let θ^nMLE\etthn^{MLE}θ^nMLE​ be the maximum likelihood estimator, and

(4.9)θ^nc=argmax⁡θ∈Θ0ℓn(θ)\tag{4.9}\etthn^c = \argmax{\theta \in \Theta_0}\ell_n(\theta)θ^nc​=θ∈Θ0​argmax​ℓn​(θ)(4.9)

be the constrained maximum likelihood estimator under the null hypothesis. The likelihood ratio test statistic:

(4.10)Tn=2(ℓn(θ^nMLE)−ℓn(θ^nc))\tag{4.10}T_n = 2\left(\ell_n(\etthn^{MLE}) - \ell_n(\etthn^c)\right)Tn​=2(ℓn​(θ^nMLE​)−ℓn​(θ^nc​))(4.10)

Wilk's Theorem: under H0H_0H0​, if the MLE conditions are satisfied:

(4.11)Tn→n→∞(d)χd−r2\tag{4.11}T_n \convd \chi^2_{d-r}Tn​(d)n→∞​χd−r2​(4.11)

The corresponding test with level α\alphaα is:

ψα=1{Tn>qα(χd−r2)}\psi_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha(\chi^2_{d-r})\}ψα​=1{Tn​>qα​(χd−r2​)}

Implicit testing: let g:Rd→Rkg: \R^d \rightarrow \R^kg:Rd→Rk continuously differentiable, k≤dk \leq dk≤d. We want to test H0:g(θ)=0H_0: g(\theta) = 0H0​:g(θ)=0 against H1:g(θ)≠0H_1: g(\theta) \neq 0H1​:g(θ)̸​=0. By applying the Delta Method:

n(g(θ^n)−g(θ))→n→∞(d)Nk(0k,∇g(θ)TΣ(θ)∇g(θ)⎵Γ(θ))\sqrt{n}\left(g(\etthn) - g(\tth)\right) \convd \Norm_k(\zz_k, \underbrace{\nabla g(\tth)^T\SSigma(\tth)\nabla g(\tth)}_{\Gamma(\tth)})n​(g(θ^n​)−g(θ))(d)n→∞​Nk​(0k​,Γ(θ)∇g(θ)TΣ(θ)∇g(θ)​​)

If ∇g(θ)\nabla g(\tth)∇g(θ) has rank kkk and Γ(θ)\Gamma(\tth)Γ(θ) is invertible and continuous, we can apply the Wald's Test method:

(4.12)Tn=ng(θ^n)TΓ−1(θ^n)g(θ^n)→n→∞(d)χk2\tag{4.12}T_n = ng(\etthn)^T\Gamma^{-1}(\etthn)g(\etthn) \convd \chi^2_kTn​=ng(θ^n​)TΓ−1(θ^n​)g(θ^n​)(d)n→∞​χk2​(4.12)

The corresponding test with level α\alphaα is:

ψα=1{Tn>qα(χk2)}\psi_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha(\chi^2_k)\}ψα​=1{Tn​>qα​(χk2​)}

Lecture 15: Goodness of Fit Test for Discrete Distributions

Categorical distribution: let E={a1,…,ak}E = \{a_1, \ldots, a_k\}E={a1​,…,ak​} be a finite space and (Pp)p∈ΔK(\P_\pp)_{\pp \in \Delta_K}(Pp​)p∈ΔK​​ be the family of all distributions over EEE:

(4.13)ΔK={p∈(0,1)K,∑i=1Kpi=1}\tag{4.13}\Delta_K = \left\{\pp \in (0, 1)^K, \sum_{i=1}^Kp_i = 1\right\}ΔK​={p∈(0,1)K,i=1∑K​pi​=1}(4.13)

The distribution of X∼PpX \sim \P_\ppX∼Pp​ is defined by

(4.14)∀i∈[​[1,K]​],Pp(X=ai)=pi\tag{4.14}\forall i \in \lb 1, K \rb, \P_\pp(X = a_i) = p_i∀i∈[[1,K]],Pp​(X=ai​)=pi​(4.14)

Goodness of fit test: let us consider p,p0∈ΔK\pp, \pp^0 \in \Delta_Kp,p0∈ΔK​, and X1,…,Xn∼i.i.dPp\Xton \iid \P_\ppX1​,…,Xn​∼i.i.dPp​. We want to test H0:p=p0H_0: \pp = \pp^0H0​:p=p0 against H1:p≠=pp0H_1: \pp \neq =pp^0H1​:p̸​==pp0.

For example, we can test against the uniform distribution p0=(1/K,…,1/K)T\pp^0 = (1/K, \ldots, 1/K)^Tp0=(1/K,…,1/K)T.

Under the constraint ∑ipi=1\sum_ip_i = 1∑i​pi​=1, the MLE is:

(4.15)∀j∈[​[1,K]​],p^j=Njn\tag{4.15}\forall j \in \lb 1, K \rb, \hat\pp_j = \frac{N_j}{n}∀j∈[[1,K]],p^​j​=nNj​​(4.15)

where Nj=∣{Xi=aj,i∈[​[1,n]​]}∣N_j = |\{X_i = a_j, i \in \lb 1, n \rb\}|Nj​=∣{Xi​=aj​,i∈[[1,n]]}∣ is the number of occurences of the jjj-th element in the data.

Theorem: under H0H_0H0​,

(4.16)Tn=n∑j=1K(p^j−pj0)2pj0→n→∞(d)χK−12\tag{4.16}T_n = n\sum_{j=1}^K\frac{(\hat\pp_j - \pp^0_j)^2}{\pp^0_j} \convd \chi^2_{K-1}Tn​=nj=1∑K​pj0​(p^​j​−pj0​)2​(d)n→∞​χK−12​(4.16)

The associated test therefore is:

ψα=1{Tn>qα(χK−12)}\psi_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha(\chi^2_{K-1})\}ψα​=1{Tn​>qα​(χK−12​)}

If, instead of testing against a single parameter p0\pp^0p0, we want to test against a family of distributions, i.e. if we have the following problem:

H0:Pp∈{Pθ}θ∈Θ,H1:Pp̸∈{Pθ}θ∈ΘH_0: \P_\pp \in \{\P_\theta\}_{\theta \in \Theta}, \quad H_1: \P_\pp \not\in \{\P_\theta\}_{\theta \in \Theta}H0​:Pp​∈{Pθ​}θ∈Θ​,H1​:Pp​̸​∈{Pθ​}θ∈Θ​

with Θ⊆Rd,d∈N∗\Theta \subseteq \R^d, d \in \N^*Θ⊆Rd,d∈N∗, then the test statistic is

(4.17)Tn=n∑j=1K(p^j−Pθ^(X=aj))2Pθ^(X=aj)→n→∞(d)χK−1−d2\tag{4.17}T_n = n\sum_{j=1}^K\frac{(\hat\pp_j - \P_{\eth}(X=a_j))^2}{\P_{\eth}(X=a_j)} \convd \chi^2_{K-1-d}Tn​=nj=1∑K​Pθ^​(X=aj​)(p^​j​−Pθ^​(X=aj​))2​(d)n→∞​χK−1−d2​(4.17)

where θ^\ethθ^ is the MLE estimator of θ\thetaθ given the data.

For example, let us test against any binomial distribution Binom(N,p)\mathcal{Binom}(N, p)Binom(N,p) where ppp is unknown. The support is of cardinal n+1n+1n+1, hence K=N+1K = N+1K=N+1, and the dimension of Θ\ThetaΘ is d=1d=1d=1; hence, the asymptotic distribution is χK−1−d2=χN−12\chi^2_{K-1-d} = \chi^2_{N-1}χK−1−d2​=χN−12​.

Lecture 16: Goodness of Fit Test Continued: Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, Kolmogorov-Lilliefors test, Quantile-Quantile Plots

Let X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​ be i.i.d random variables. The CDF of a random variable XXX is defined as:

∀t∈R,F(t)=P[X≤t]\forall t \in \R, F(t) = \P[X \leq t]∀t∈R,F(t)=P[X≤t]

The empirical CDF of the sample X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​ is defined as:

(4.18)Fn(t)=1n∑i=1n1{Xi≤t}=∣{Xi≤t,i∈[​[1,n]​]}∣n\tag{4.18}F_n(t) = \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n\one\{X_i \leq t\} = \frac{|\{X_i \leq t, i \in \lb 1, n \rb\}|}nFn​(t)=n1​i=1∑n​1{Xi​≤t}=n∣{Xi​≤t,i∈[[1,n]]}∣​(4.18)

The Glivenko-Cantelli Theorem (Fundamental theorem of statistics) gives us:

(4.19)sup⁡t∈R∣Fn(t)−F(t)∣→n→∞a.s.0\tag{4.19}\sup_{t\in\R}|F_n(t) - F(t)| \convas 0t∈Rsup​∣Fn​(t)−F(t)∣a.s.n→∞​0(4.19)

By the central limit theorem, as P[X≤t]=F(t)\P[X \leq t] = F(t)P[X≤t]=F(t) corresponds to a Bernoulli distribution, we know that:

(4.20)∀t∈R,n(Fn(t)−F(t))→n→∞(d)N(0,F(t)(1−F(t)))\tag{4.20}\forall t \in \R, \sqrt{n}(F_n(t) - F(t)) \convd \Norm(0, F(t)(1 - F(t)))∀t∈R,n​(Fn​(t)−F(t))(d)n→∞​N(0,F(t)(1−F(t)))(4.20)

Donsker's Theorem: if FFF is continuous, then

(4.21)nsup⁡t∈R∣Fn(t)−F(t)∣→n→∞(d)sup⁡t∈[0,1]∣B(t)∣\tag{4.21}\sqrt{n}\sup_{t\in\R}|F_n(t) - F(t)| \convd \sup_{t \in [0, 1]} |\B(t)|n​t∈Rsup​∣Fn​(t)−F(t)∣(d)n→∞​t∈[0,1]sup​∣B(t)∣(4.21)

where B\BB is the Brownian bridge distribution over [0,1][0, 1][0,1], and more importantly, a pivot distribution.

Kolmogorov-Smirnov test: let X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​ be i.i.d random variables with unknown CDF FFF. Let F0F^0F0 be a continuous CDF. We want to test H0:F=F0H_0: F = F^0H0​:F=F0 against H1:F≠F0H_1: F \neq F^0H1​:F̸​=F0. Let FnF_nFn​ be the empirical CDF of the sample. Then, under H0H_0H0​:

Tn=nsup⁡t∈R∣Fn(t)−F0(t)∣→n→∞(d)Z∼sup⁡t∈[0,1]∣B(t)∣T_n = \sqrt{n}\sup_{t \in \R}|F_n(t) - F^0(t)| \convd Z \sim \sup_{t \in [0, 1]}|\B(t)|Tn​=n​t∈Rsup​∣Fn​(t)−F0(t)∣(d)n→∞​Z∼t∈[0,1]sup​∣B(t)∣

The associated test is the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, with level α\alphaα:

(4.22)δαKS=1{Tn>qα(Z)}\tag{4.22}\delta^{KS}_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha(Z)\}δαKS​=1{Tn​>qα​(Z)}(4.22)

Please be careful: some tables gives the values for Tnn\frac{T_n}{\sqrt{n}}n​Tn​​, instead of TnT_nTn​.

We can compute TnT_nTn​ with a formula, using the property that F0F^0F0 is increasing and FnF_nFn​ piecewise constant. Let us reorder our samples X(1)≤X(2)≤…≤X(n)X_{(1)} \leq X_{(2)} \leq \ldots \leq X_{(n)}X(1)​≤X(2)​≤…≤X(n)​. Then:

(4.23)Tn=nmax⁡i∈[​[1,n]​](max⁡(∣i−1n−F0(X(i))∣,∣in−F0(X(i))∣))\tag{4.23}T_n = \sqrt{n}\max_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}\left(\max\left(\left|\frac{i-1}n - F^0(X_{(i)})\right|, \left|\frac{i}n - F^0(X_{(i)})\right|\right)\right)Tn​=n​i∈[[1,n]]max​(max(∣∣∣∣​ni−1​−F0(X(i)​)∣∣∣∣​,∣∣∣∣​ni​−F0(X(i)​)∣∣∣∣​))(4.23)

Pivotal distribution: let us consider Ui=F0(Xi)U_i = F^0(X_i)Ui​=F0(Xi​), with associated empirical CDF GnG_nGn​. Under H0H_0H0​, U1,…,Un∼i.i.dUnif(0,1)U_1, \ldots, U_n \iid \Unif(0, 1)U1​,…,Un​∼i.i.dUnif(0,1) and

Tn=nsup⁡x∈[0,1]∣Gn(x)−x∣T_n = \sqrt{n}\sup_{x \in [0, 1]}|G_n(x) - x|Tn​=n​x∈[0,1]sup​∣Gn​(x)−x∣

Which justifies that TnT_nTn​ is indeed a pivotal statistic.

To estimate the quantiles numerically, as long as we can generate random values along a uniform distribution, we can therefore proceed as follows:

  • With MMM large, simulate MMM copies of TnT_nTn​, Tn1,…,TnMT_n^1, \ldots, T_n^MTn1​,…,TnM​,
  • Estimate the qα(Tn)q_\alpha(T_n)qα​(Tn​) quantile with q^αM(Tn)\hat{q}_\alpha^M(T_n)q^​αM​(Tn​) by finding the 1−α1-\alpha1−α sample cutoff among the TnmT_n^mTnm​,
  • Apply the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test with δα=1{Tn>q^αM(Tn)}\delta_\alpha = \one\{T_n > \hat{q}_\alpha^M(T_n)\}δα​=1{Tn​>q^​αM​(Tn​)}.

The ppp-value is then given by:

p-value⁡≈∣{Tnm>Tn,m∈[​[1,M]​]}∣M\pval \approx \frac{|\{T_n^m > T_n, m \in \lb 1, M \rb \}|}Mp-value≈M∣{Tnm​>Tn​,m∈[[1,M]]}∣​

Other distances can measure the difference between two functions than the sup⁡\supsup. For example, the Cramér-Von Mises and the Anderson-Darling distances:

dCVM(Fn,F)=∫R(Fn(t)−F(t))2dF(t)=EF[(Fn(X)−F(X))2]d^{CVM}(F_n, F) = \int_\R(F_n(t) - F(t))^2dF(t) = \E_F[(F_n(X) - F(X))^2]dCVM(Fn​,F)=∫R​(Fn​(t)−F(t))2dF(t)=EF​[(Fn​(X)−F(X))2]
dAD(Fn,F)=∫R(Fn(t)−F(t))2F(t)(1−F(t))dF(t)=EF[(Fn(t)−F(t))2F(t)(1−F(t))]d^{AD}(F_n, F) = \int_\R\frac{(F_n(t) - F(t))^2}{F(t)(1-F(t))}dF(t) = \E_F\left[\frac{(F_n(t) - F(t))^2}{F(t)(1-F(t))}\right]dAD(Fn​,F)=∫R​F(t)(1−F(t))(Fn​(t)−F(t))2​dF(t)=EF​[F(t)(1−F(t))(Fn​(t)−F(t))2​]

The Kolmogorov-Smirnov test is not valid against a family of distributions. For example, if we want to test if XXX has any Gaussian distribution, we cannot simply plugin the estimators μ^,σ2^\hat\mu, \est{\sigma^2}μ^​,σ2 into the Kolmogorov-Smirnov estimator.

Kolmogorov-Lilliefors test. However, for a Gaussian distribution,

Tn=sup⁡t∈R∣Fn(t)−Φμ^,σ2^(t)∣∼ZnT_n = \sup_{t\in \R}|F_n(t) - \Phi_{\hat\mu, \est{\sigma^2}}(t)| \sim Z_nTn​=t∈Rsup​∣Fn​(t)−Φμ^​,σ2​(t)∣∼Zn​

does not depend on any parameter; as such, it is a pivotal statistic, and gives us the Kolmogorov-Lilliefors test:

(4.24)δαKL=1{Tn>qα(Zn)}\tag{4.24}\delta^{KL}_\alpha = \one\{T_n > q_\alpha(Z_n)\}δαKL​=1{Tn​>qα​(Zn​)}(4.24)

Quantile-quantile (QQ) plots: informal visual cues to decide whether it's likely a distribution is close to another one. Given a sample CDF FnF_nFn​ and a target CDF FFF, we plot:

(4.25)(F−1(1n),Fn−1(1n)),(F−1(2n),Fn−1(2n)),…,(F−1(n−1n),Fn−1(n−1n))\tag{4.25}\left(F^{-1}\left(\frac1n\right), F_n^{-1}\left(\frac1n\right)\right), \left(F^{-1}\left(\frac2n\right), F_n^{-1}\left(\frac2n\right)\right), \ldots, \left(F^{-1}\left(\frac{n-1}n\right), F_n^{-1}\left(\frac{n-1}n\right)\right)(F−1(n1​),Fn−1​(n1​)),(F−1(n2​),Fn−1​(n2​)),…,(F−1(nn−1​),Fn−1​(nn−1​))(4.25)

If the plot is aligned along the y=xy = xy=x axis, they are likely close to each other. There are four patterns of differences between distributions:

  • Heavier tails: below > above the diagonal.
  • Lighter tails: above > below the diagonal.
  • Right-skewed: above > below > above the diagonal.
  • Left-skewed: below > above > below the diagonal.

Unit 5: Bayesian Statistics

Lecture 17: Introduction to Bayesian Statistics

Bayesian inference conceptually amounts to weight the likelihood Ln(θ)L_n(\theta)Ln​(θ) by a prior knowledge we might have on θ\thetaθ.

Given a statistical model (E,(Pθ)θ∈Θ)\statmodel(E,(Pθ​)θ∈Θ​), we technically model our parameter θ\tthθ as if it were a random variable. We therefore define a prior distribution (PDF):

π(θ)\pi(\tth)π(θ)

Let X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​. We note Ln(X1,…,Xn∣θ)L_n(\Xton|\tth)Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​∣θ) the joint probability distribution of X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​ conditioned on θ\tthθ where θ∼π\tth \sim \piθ∼π. This is exactly the likelihood from the frequentist approach.

Bayes' formula. The posterior distribution verifies:

(5.1)∀θ∈Θ,π(θ∣X1,…,Xn)∝π(θ)Ln(X1,…,Xn∣θ)\tag{5.1}\forall \tth \in \Theta, \pi(\tth|\Xton) \propto \pi(\tth)L_n(\Xton | \tth)∀θ∈Θ,π(θ∣X1​,…,Xn​)∝π(θ)Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​∣θ)(5.1)

The constant is the normalization factor to ensure the result is a proper distribution, and does not depend on θ\tthθ:

π(θ∣X1,…,Xn)=π(θ)Ln(X1,…,Xn∣θ)∫Θπ(θ)Ln(X1,…,Xn∣θ)dθ\pi(\tth|\Xton) = \frac{\pi(\tth)L_n(\Xton | \tth)}{\int_\Theta\pi(\tth)L_n(\Xton | \tth)d\tth}π(θ∣X1​,…,Xn​)=∫Θ​π(θ)Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​∣θ)dθπ(θ)Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​∣θ)​

We can often use an improper prior, i.e. a prior that is not a proper probability distribution (whose integral diverges), and still get a proper posterior. For example, the improper prior π(θ)=1\pi(\tth) = 1π(θ)=1 on Θ\ThetaΘ gives the likelihood as a posterior.

Jeffreys Prior: it is defined as:

(5.2)πJ(θ)∝det⁡I(θ)\tag{5.2} \pi_J(\tth) \propto \sqrt{\det I(\tth)}πJ​(θ)∝detI(θ)​(5.2)

where I(θ)I(\tth)I(θ) is the Fisher information. This prior is invariant by reparametrization, which means that if we have η=ϕ(θ)\eeta = \phi(\tth)η=ϕ(θ), then the same prior gives us a probability distribution for η\eetaη verifying:

(5.3)π~J(η)∝det⁡I~(η)\tag{5.3}\tilde\pi_J(\eeta) \propto \sqrt{\det \tilde I(\eeta)}π~J​(η)∝detI~(η)​(5.3)

The change of parameter follows the following formula:

(5.4)π~J(η)=det⁡(∇ϕ−1(η))πJ(θ)\tag{5.4}\tilde\pi_J(\eeta) = \det(\nabla \phi^{-1}(\eeta)) \pi_J(\tth)π~J​(η)=det(∇ϕ−1(η))πJ​(θ)(5.4)

Bayesian confidence region. Let α∈(0,1)\alpha \in (0, 1)α∈(0,1). A Bayesian confidence region with level α\alphaα is a random subset R⊂Θ\mathcal{R} \subset \ThetaR⊂Θ depending on X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​ (and the prior π\piπ) such that:

(5.5)P[θ∈R∣X1,…,Xn]≥1−α\tag{5.5}\P[\tth \in \mathcal{R} | \Xton] \geq 1 - \alphaP[θ∈R∣X1​,…,Xn​]≥1−α(5.5)

Bayesian confidence region and confidence interval are distinct notions.

The Bayesian framework can be used to estimate the true underlying parameter. In that case, it is used to build a new class of estimators, based on the posterior distribution.

The Bayes estimator (posterior mean) is defined as:

(5.6)θ^(π)=∫Θθπ(θ∣X1,…,Xn)dθ\tag{5.6}\etth_{(\pi)} = \int_\Theta\tth\pi(\tth | \Xton)d\tthθ^(π)​=∫Θ​θπ(θ∣X1​,…,Xn​)dθ(5.6)

The Maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimator is defined as:

(5.7)θ^(π)MAP=argmax⁡θ∈Θπ(θ∣X1,…,Xn)\tag{5.7}\etth^{MAP}_{(\pi)} = \argmax{\theta\in\Theta}\pi(\tth | \Xton)θ^(π)MAP​=θ∈Θargmax​π(θ∣X1​,…,Xn​)(5.7)

The MAP is equivalent to the MLE, if the prior is uniform.

Lecture 18: Jeffrey's Prior and Bayesian Confidence Interval

Description [A.3]

Properties [A.3]

Maximum likelihood estimator (for fixed NNN):

(A.3.4)p^n=∑iXinN\tag{A.3.4} \hat{p}_n = \frac{\sum_iX_i}{nN}p^​n​=nN∑i​Xi​​(A.3.4)

Part 4: Categorical distribution

Description [A.4]

Notation: Cat(p)\mathcal{Cat}(\pp)Cat(p)

Parameters: p∈ΔK={p∈(0,1)K,∑kpk=1}\pp \in \Delta_K = \{\pp \in (0, 1)^K, \sum_kp_k = 1\}p∈ΔK​={p∈(0,1)K,∑k​pk​=1}

Support: E={a1,…,aK}∼[​[1,K]​]E = \{a_1, \ldots, a_K\} \sim \lb 1, K \rbE={a1​,…,aK​}∼[[1,K]]

Probability mass function (PMF):

(A.4.1)fp(ak)=pk\tag{A.4.1} f_\pp(a_k) = p_kfp​(ak​)=pk​(A.4.1)

Properties [A.4]

Given a sample X1,…,Xn\XtonX1​,…,Xn​, we define the number of occurences of each outcome:

∀k∈[​[1,K]​],Nk=∑i=1n1{Xi=ak}=∣{i∈[​[1,n]​],Xi=ak}∣\forall k \in \lb 1, K \rb, N_k = \sum_{i=1}^n\one\{X_i = a_k\} = |\{i \in \lb 1, n \rb, X_i = a_k\}|∀k∈[[1,K]],Nk​=i=1∑n​1{Xi​=ak​}=∣{i∈[[1,n]],Xi​=ak​}∣

Likelihood:

(A.4.1)Ln(X1,…,Xn,p)=∏k=1KpkNk\tag{A.4.1} L_n(\Xton, \pp) = \prod_{k=1}^Kp_k^{N_k}Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​,p)=k=1∏K​pkNk​​(A.4.1)

Log-likelihood:

(A.4.2)ℓn(X1,…,Xn,p)=∑k=1KNkln⁡pk\tag{A.4.2} \ell_n(\Xton, \pp) = \sum_{k=1}^KN_k\ln p_kℓn​(X1​,…,Xn​,p)=k=1∑K​Nk​lnpk​(A.4.2)

Maximum likelihood estimator (under the constraint ∑kpk=1\sum_kp_k = 1∑k​pk​=1):

(A.4.3)∀k∈[​[1,K]​],p^n=(N1n,…,NKn)\tag{A.4.3} \forall k \in \lb 1, K \rb, \hat{\pp}_n = \left(\frac{N_1}n, \ldots, \frac{N_K}n\right)∀k∈[[1,K]],p^​n​=(nN1​​,…,nNK​​)(A.4.3)

Part 5: Poisson distribution

Description [A.5]

Notation: Poiss(λ)\Poiss(\lambda)Poiss(λ)

Parameters: λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0

Support: E=NE = \NE=N

Probability mass function (PMF):

(A.5.1)fλ(k)=λke−λk!\tag{A.5.1} f_\lambda(k) = \frac{\lambda^ke^{-\lambda}}{k!}fλ​(k)=k!λke−λ​(A.5.1)

Properties [A.5]

Mean: E[X]=λ\E[X] = \lambdaE[X]=λ

Variance: V[X]=λ\V[X] = \lambdaV[X]=λ

Fischer information: I(λ)=1λI(\lambda) = \frac1\lambdaI(λ)=λ1​

Likelihood:

(A.5.2)Ln(X1,…,Xn,λ)=1∏i=1nXi!λ∑i=1nXie−nλ\tag{A.5.2} L_n(\Xton, \lambda) = \frac{1}{\discr \prod_{i=1}^nX_i!} \lambda^{\discr \sum_{i=1}^nX_i} e^{-n\lambda}Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​,λ)=i=1∏n​Xi​!1​λi=1∑n​Xi​e−nλ(A.5.2)

Log-likelihood:

(A.5.3)ℓn(X1,…,Xn,λ)=ln⁡λ∑i=1nXi−nλ−∑i=1nln⁡(Xi!)\tag{A.5.3} \ell_n(\Xton, \lambda) = \ln\lambda\sum_{i=1}^nX_i - n\lambda - \sum_{i=1}^n\ln(X_i!)ℓn​(X1​,…,Xn​,λ)=lnλi=1∑n​Xi​−nλ−i=1∑n​ln(Xi​!)(A.5.3)

Maximum likelihood estimator:

(A.5.4)λ^n=Xˉn=1n∑i=1nXi\tag{A.5.4} \hat{\lambda}_n = \bar{X}_n = \frac1n\sum_{i=1}^nX_iλ^n​=Xˉn​=n1​i=1∑n​Xi​(A.5.4)

Part 6: Uniform distribution

Description [A.6]

Notation: Unif(a,b)\Unif(a, b)Unif(a,b)

Parameters: a,b∈R,a<ba, b \in \R, a < ba,b∈R,a<b (usually, a=0a = 0a=0)

Support: E=[a,b]⊂RE = [a, b] \subset \RE=[a,b]⊂R

Probability density function (PDF):

(A.6.1)fa,b(x)=1b−a1{a≤x≤b}\tag{A.6.1} f_{a, b}(x) = \frac1{b-a}\one\{a \leq x \leq b\}fa,b​(x)=b−a1​1{a≤x≤b}(A.6.1)

Cumulative density function (CDF):

(A.6.2)Fa,b(x)={0ifx<ax−ab−aifa≤x≤b1ifx>b\tag{A.6.2} F_{a, b}(x) = \begin{cases}\displaystyle 0 & \text{if}\quad x < a \\ \displaystyle \frac{x-a}{b-a} & \text{if}\quad a \leq x \leq b \\ \displaystyle 1 & \text{if}\quad x > b \end{cases}Fa,b​(x)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​0b−ax−a​1​ifx<aifa≤x≤bifx>b​(A.6.2)

Properties [A.6]

Mean: E[X]=a+b2\E[X] = \frac{a+b}2E[X]=2a+b​

Variance: V[X]=112(b−a)2\V[X] = \frac1{12}(b-a)^2V[X]=121​(b−a)2

Moments: E[Xk]=1n+1∑i=0kaibk−i\E[X^k] = \frac{1}{n+1}\sum_{i=0}^ka^ib^{k-i}E[Xk]=n+11​∑i=0k​aibk−i

Likelihood:

(A.6.3)Ln(X1,…,Xn,a,b)=1(b−a)n1{min⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi≥a}1{max⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi≤b}\tag{A.6.3} L_n(\Xton, a, b) = \frac1{(b - a)^n}\one\left\{\min_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_i \geq a\right\}\one\left\{\max_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_i \leq b\right\}Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​,a,b)=(b−a)n1​1{i∈[[1,n]]min​Xi​≥a}1{i∈[[1,n]]max​Xi​≤b}(A.6.3)

Log-likelihood:

(A.6.4)ℓn(X1,…,Xn,a,b)=nln⁡1b−a+ln⁡1{min⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi≥a}+ln⁡1{max⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi≤b}\tag{A.6.4} \ell_n(\Xton, a, b) = n\ln\frac1{b-a} + \ln\one\left\{\min_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_i \geq a\right\} + \ln\one\left\{\max_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_i \leq b\right\}ℓn​(X1​,…,Xn​,a,b)=nlnb−a1​+ln1{i∈[[1,n]]min​Xi​≥a}+ln1{i∈[[1,n]]max​Xi​≤b}(A.6.4)

Maximum likelihood estimator (cannot differentiate the log-likelihood):

(A.6.5)a^n=min⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi,b^n=max⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi\tag{A.6.5} \hat{a}_n = \min_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_i, \quad \hat{b}_n = \max_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_ia^n​=i∈[[1,n]]min​Xi​,b^n​=i∈[[1,n]]max​Xi​(A.6.5)

Part 7: Exponential distribution

Description [A.7]

Notation: Exp(λ)\Exp(\lambda)Exp(λ)

Parameters: λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0

Support: E=[0,+∞)E = [0, +\infty)E=[0,+∞)

Probability density function (PDF):

(A.7.1)fλ(x)=λe−λx1{x≥0}\tag{A.7.1} f_\lambda(x) = \lambda e^{-\lambda x}\one\{x \geq 0\}fλ​(x)=λe−λx1{x≥0}(A.7.1)

Cumulative density function (CDF):

(A.7.2)Fλ(x)=(1−e−λx)1{x≥0}\tag{A.7.2} F_\lambda(x) = (1 - e^{-\lambda x})\one\{x \geq 0\}Fλ​(x)=(1−e−λx)1{x≥0}(A.7.2)

Properties [A.7]

Mean: E[X]=1λ\E[X] = \frac1\lambdaE[X]=λ1​

Variance: V[X]=1λ2\V[X] = \frac1{\lambda^2}V[X]=λ21​

Moments: E[Xk]=k!λk\E[X^k] = \frac{k!}{\lambda^k}E[Xk]=λkk!​

Fischer Information: I(λ)=1λ2I(\lambda) = \frac1{\lambda^2}I(λ)=λ21​

Likelihood:

(A.7.3)Ln(X1,…,Xn,λ)=λnexp⁡(−λ∑i=1nXi)1{min⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi≥0}\tag{A.7.3} L_n(\Xton, \lambda) = \lambda^n \exp\left(-\lambda \sum_{i=1}^nX_i\right)\one\left\{\min_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_i \geq 0\right\}Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​,λ)=λnexp(−λi=1∑n​Xi​)1{i∈[[1,n]]min​Xi​≥0}(A.7.3)

Log-likelihood:

(A.7.4)ℓn(X1,…,Xn,λ)=nln⁡λ−λ∑i=1nXi+ln⁡1{min⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi≥0}\tag{A.7.4} \ell_n(\Xton, \lambda) = n\ln\lambda - \lambda\sum_{i=1}^nX_i+\ln\one\left\{\min_{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_i \geq 0\right\}ℓn​(X1​,…,Xn​,λ)=nlnλ−λi=1∑n​Xi​+ln1{i∈[[1,n]]min​Xi​≥0}(A.7.4)

Maximum likelihood estimator:

(A.7.5)λ^n=n∑iXi=1Xˉn\tag{A.7.5} \hat{\lambda}_n = \frac{n}{\sum_iX_i} = \frac1{\bar{X}_n}λ^n​=∑i​Xi​n​=Xˉn​1​(A.7.5)

Memorylessness: P[X>s+t∣X>s]=P[X>t]\P[X > s+t | X > s] = \P[X > t]P[X>s+t∣X>s]=P[X>t]

Part 10: Laplace distribution

Description [A.10]

Notation: Lapl(μ,b)\mathcal{Lapl}(\mu, b)Lapl(μ,b)

Support: E=RE = \RE=R

Probability density function (PDF):

(A.10.1)fμ,b(x)=12bexp⁡(−∣x−μ∣b)\tag{A.10.1} f_{\mu, b}(x) = \frac{1}{2b}\exp\left(-\frac{|x-\mu|}{b}\right)fμ,b​(x)=2b1​exp(−b∣x−μ∣​)(A.10.1)

Cumulative density function (CDF):

(A.10.2)Fμ,b(x)={12exp⁡(x−μb)ifx≤μ1−12exp⁡(μ−xb)ifx>μ\tag{A.10.2} F_{\mu, b}(x) = \begin{cases} \displaystyle \frac12\exp\left(\frac{x-\mu}{b}\right) & \text{if}\quad x \leq \mu \\ \displaystyle 1 - \frac12\exp\left(\frac{\mu - x}{b}\right) & \text{if}\quad x > \mu \end{cases}Fμ,b​(x)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​21​exp(bx−μ​)1−21​exp(bμ−x​)​ifx≤μifx>μ​(A.10.2)

(A.10.3)Ln(X1,…,Xn,μ,b)=1(2b)nexp⁡(−1b∑i=1n∣Xi−μ∣)\tag{A.10.3} L_n(\Xton, \mu, b) = \frac1{(2b)^n}\exp\left(-\frac1b\sum_{i=1}^n|X_i - \mu|\right)Ln​(X1​,…,Xn​,μ,b)=(2b)n1​exp(−b1​i=1∑n​∣Xi​−μ∣)(A.10.3)

(A.10.4)ℓn(X1,…,Xn,μ,b)=−nln⁡2−nln⁡b−1b∑i=1n∣Xi−μ∣\tag{A.10.4} \ell_n(\Xton, \mu, b) = -n\ln2 -n\ln b - \frac1b\sum_{i=1}^n|X_i - \mu|ℓn​(X1​,…,Xn​,μ,b)=−nln2−nlnb−b1​i=1∑n​∣Xi​−μ∣(A.10.4)

μ^n=Med⁡i∈[​[1,n]​]Xi,b^n=1n∑i=1n∣Xi−μ^∣\hat{\mu}_n = \Med{i \in \lb 1, n \rb}X_i, \quad \hat{b}_n = \frac{1}n\sum_{i=1}^n|X_i - \hat{\mu}|μ^​n​=i∈[[1,n]]Med​Xi​,b^n​=n1​i=1∑n​∣Xi​−μ^​∣

Part 11: Chi-squared distribution

Description [A.11]

Notation: χd2\chi^2_dχd2​ (ddd fixed)

Support: E=[0,+∞)E = [0, +\infty)E=[0,+∞)

Definition: Z12+…Zd2∼χd2Z_1^2 + \ldots Z_d^2 \sim \chi^2_dZ12​+…Zd2​∼χd2​, where Z1,…,Zd∼i.i.dN(0,1)Z_1, \ldots, Z_d \iid \Norm(0, 1)Z1​,…,Zd​∼i.i.dN(0,1).

Probability density function (PDF):

(A.11.1)fd(x)=12d/2Γ(d/2)xd/2−1e−x/2\tag{A.11.1} f_d(x) = \frac{1}{2^{d/2}\Gamma(d/2)}x^{d/2-1}e^{-x/2}fd​(x)=2d/2Γ(d/2)1​xd/2−1e−x/2(A.11.1)

Properties [A.11]

Variance: V[X]=2d\V[X] = 2dV[X]=2d

Useful for many test statistics as a pivot distribution.

Part 12: Beta distribution

Description [A.12]

Notation: β(a,b)\beta(a, b)β(a,b)

Parameters: a,b∈(0,+∞)a, b \in (0, +\infty)a,b∈(0,+∞)

Support: E=[0,1]E = [0, 1]E=[0,1] or (0,1)(0, 1)(0,1)

Probability density function (PDF):

(A.12.1)fa,b(x)=xa−1(1−x)b−1B(a,b)\tag{A.12.1} f_{a, b}(x) = \frac{x^{a-1}(1-x)^{b-1}}{B(a, b)}fa,b​(x)=B(a,b)xa−1(1−x)b−1​(A.12.1)

where B(a,b)=Γ(a)Γ(b)Γ(a+b)B(a, b) = \frac{\Gamma(a)\Gamma(b)}{\Gamma(a+b)}B(a,b)=Γ(a+b)Γ(a)Γ(b)​.

Properties [A.12]

Mean: E[X]=aa+b\E[X] = \frac{a}{a+b}E[X]=a+ba​

Mode: Mode⁡(X)=a−1a+b−2\Mode(X) = \frac{a - 1}{a + b - 2}Mode(X)=a+b−2a−1​

Variance: V[X]=ab(a+b)2(a+b+1)\V[X] = \frac{ab}{(a+b)^2(a+b+1)}V[X]=(a+b)2(a+b+1)ab​

Useful as the Bayesian conjugate for Bernoulli distributions.

Part 13: Gamma distribution

Description [A.13]

Notation: Gamma(α,β)\mathcal{Gamma}(\alpha, \beta)Gamma(α,β)

Parameters: α,β∈(0,+∞)\alpha, \beta \in (0, +\infty)α,β∈(0,+∞)

Support: E=(0,+∞)E = (0, +\infty)E=(0,+∞)

Probability density function (PDF):

(A.13.1)fα,β(x)=βαΓ(α)xα−1e−βx\tag{A.13.1} f_{\alpha, \beta}(x) = \frac{\beta^\alpha}{\Gamma(\alpha)}x^{\alpha-1}e^{-\beta x}fα,β​(x)=Γ(α)βα​xα−1e−βx(A.13.1)

Properties [A.13]

Mean: E[X]=αβ\E[X] = \frac{\alpha}{\beta}E[X]=βα​

Mode: Mode⁡(X)=α−1β\Mode(X) = \frac{\alpha - 1}{\beta}Mode(X)=βα−1​

Variance: V[X]=αβ2\V[X] = \frac{\alpha}{\beta^2}V[X]=β2α​

Useful as the Bayesian conjugate for exponential distributions.
